verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 1:1
verses.text: Theodoret, Book II.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 1:2
verses.text: Chapter I.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 1:3
verses.text: —Return of St.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 1:4
verses.text: Athanasius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 1:5
verses.text: The divine Athanasius returned to Alexandria, after having remained two years and four months at Treves.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 1:6
verses.text: Constantine, the eldest son of Constantine the Great, whose imperial sway extended over Western Gaul, wrote the following letter to the church of Alexandria.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 1:7
verses.text: Epistle of the Emperor Constantine, the son of Constantine the Great, to the Alexandrians.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 1:8
verses.text: "Constantinus Caesar to the people of the Catholic Church of Alexandria.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 1:9
verses.text: "I think that it cannot have escaped your pious intelligence that Athanasius, the interpreter of the venerated law, was opportunely sent into Gaul, in order that, so long as the savagery of these bloodthirsty opponents was threatening peril to his sacred head, he might be saved from suffering irremediable wrongs.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 1:10
verses.text: To avoid this imminent peril, he was snatched from the jaws of his foes, to remain in a city under my jurisdiction, where he might be abundantly supplied with every necessary.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 1:11
verses.text: Yet the greatness of his virtue, relying on the grace of God, led him to despise all the calamities of adverse fortune.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 1:12
verses.text: Constantine, my lord and my father, of blessed memory, intended to have reinstated him in his former bishopric, and to have restored him to your piety; but as the emperor was arrested by the hand of death before his desires were accomplished, I, being his heir, have deemed it fitting to carry into execution the purpose of this sovereign of divine memory.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 1:13
verses.text: You will learn from your bishop himself, when you see him, with how much respect I have treated him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 1:14
verses.text: Nor indeed is it surprising that he should have been thus treated by me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 1:15
verses.text: I was moved to this line of conduct by his own great virtue, and the thought of your affectionate longing for his return.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 1:16
verses.text: May Divine Providence watch over you, beloved brethren!"  Furnished with this letter, St.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 1:17
verses.text: Athanasius returned from exile, and was most gladly welcomed both by the rich and by the poor, by the inhabitants of cities, and by those of the provinces.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 1:18
verses.text: The followers of the madness of Arius were the only persons who felt any vexation at his return.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 1:19
verses.text: Eusebius, Theognis, and those of their faction resorted to their former machinations, and endeavoured to prejudice the ears of the young emperor against him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 1:20
verses.text: I shall now proceed to relate in what manner Constantius swerved from the doctrines of the Apostles.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 2:1
verses.text: Chapter II.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 2:2
verses.text: —Declension of the Emperor Constantius from the true Faith.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 2:3
verses.text: Constantia, the widow of Licinius, was the half-sister of Constantine.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 2:4
verses.text: She was intimately acquainted with a certain priest who had imbibed the doctrines of Arius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 2:5
verses.text: He did not openly acknowledge his unsoundness; but, in the frequent conversations which he had with her, he did not refrain from declaring that Arius had been unjustly calumniated.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 2:6
verses.text: After the death of her impious husband, the renowned Constantine did everything in his power to solace her, and strove to prevent her from experiencing the saddest trials of widowhood.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 2:7
verses.text: He attended her also in her last illness, and rendered her every proper attention.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 2:8
verses.text: She then presented the priest whom I mentioned to the emperor, and entreated him to receive him under his protection.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 2:9
verses.text: Constantine acceded to her request, and soon after fulfilled his promise.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 2:10
verses.text: But though the priest was permitted the utmost freedom of speech, and was most honourably treated, he did not venture to reveal his corrupt principles, for he observed the firmness with which the emperor adhered to the truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 2:11
verses.text: When Constantine was on the point of being translated to an eternal kingdom, he drew up a will, in which he directed that his temporal dominions should be divided among his sons.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 2:12
verses.text: None of them was with him when he was dying, so he entrusted the will to this priest alone, and desired him to give it to Constantius, who, being at a shorter distance from the spot than his brothers, was expected to arrive the first.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 2:13
verses.text: These directions the priest executed, and thus by putting the will into his hands, became known to Constantius, who accepted him as an intimate friend, and commanded him to visit him frequently.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 2:14
verses.text: Perceiving the weakness of Constantius, whose mind was like reeds driven to and fro by the wind, he became emboldened to declare war against the doctrines of the gospel.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 2:15
verses.text: He loudly deplored the stormy state of the churches, and asserted it to be due to those who had introduced the unscriptural word "consubstantial" into the confession of faith, and that all the disputes among the clergy and the laity had been occasioned by it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 2:16
verses.text: He calumniated Athanasius and all who coincided in his opinions, and formed designs for their destruction, being used as their fellow-worker by Eusebius, Theognis, and Theodorus, bishop of Perinthus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 2:17
verses.text: The last-named, whose see is generally known by the name of Heraclea, was a man of great erudition, and had written an exposition of the Holy Scriptures.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 2:18
verses.text: These bishops resided near the emperor, and frequently visited him; they assured him that the return of Athanasius from banishment had occasioned many evils, and had excited a tempest which had shaken not only Egypt, but also Palestine, Phoenicia, and the adjacent countries.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 3:1
verses.text: Chapter III.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 3:2
verses.text: —Second Exile of St.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 3:3
verses.text: Athanasius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 3:4
verses.text: —Ordination and Death of Gregorius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 3:5
verses.text: With these and similar arguments, the bishops assailed the weak-minded emperor, and persuaded him to expel Athanasius from his church.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 3:6
verses.text: But Athanasius obtained timely intimation of their design, and departed to the west.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 3:7
verses.text: The friends of Eusebius had sent false accusations against him to Julius, who was then bishop of Rome.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 3:8
verses.text: In obedience to the laws of the church, Julius summoned the accusers and the accused to Rome, that the cause might be tried.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 3:9
verses.text: Athanasius, accordingly, set out for Rome, but the calumniators refused to go because they saw that their falsehood would easily be detected.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 3:10
verses.text: But perceiving that the flock of Athanasius was left without a pastor, they appointed over it a wolf instead of a shepherd.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 3:11
verses.text: Gregorius, for this was his name, surpassed the wild beasts in his deeds of cruelty towards the flock: but at the expiration of six years he was destroyed by the sheep themselves.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 3:12
verses.text: Athanasius went to Constans (Constantine, the eldest brother, having fallen in battle), and complained of the plots laid against him by the Arians, and of their opposition to the apostolical faith.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 3:13
verses.text: He reminded him of his father, and how he attended in person the great and famous council which he had summoned; how he was present at its debates, took part in framing its decrees, and confirmed them by law.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 3:14
verses.text: The emperor was moved to emulation by his father's zeal, and promptly wrote to his brother, exhorting him to preserve inviolate the religion of their father, which they had inherited; "for," he urged, "by piety he made his empire great, destroyed the tyrants of Rome, and subjugated the foreign nations on every side".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 3:15
verses.text: Constantius was led by this letter to summon the bishops from the east and from the west to Sardica, a city of Illyricum, and the metropolis of Dacia, that they might deliberate on the means of removing the other troubles of the church, which were many and pressing.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 4:1
verses.text: Chapter IV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 4:2
verses.text: —Paulus, Bishop of Constantinople.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 4:3
verses.text: Paulus, bishop of Constantinople, who faithfully maintained orthodox doctrines, was accused by the unsound Arians of exciting seditions, and of such other crimes as they usually laid to the charge of all those who preached true piety.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 4:4
verses.text: The people, who feared the machinations of his enemies, would not permit him to go to Sardica.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 4:5
verses.text: The Arians, taking advantage of the weakness of the emperor, procured from him an edict of banishment against Paulus, who was, accordingly, sent to Cucusus, a little town formerly included in Cappadocia, but now in Lesser Armenia.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 4:6
verses.text: But these disturbers of the public peace were not satisfied with having driven the admirable Paulus into a desert.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 4:7
verses.text: They sent the agents of their cruelty to despatch him by a violent death.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 4:8
verses.text: St.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 4:9
verses.text: Athanasius testifies to this fact in the defence which he wrote of his own flight.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 4:10
verses.text: He uses the following words: "They pursued Paulus, bishop of Constantinople, and having seized him at Cucusus, a city of Cappadocia, they had him strangled, using as their executioner Philippus the prefect, who was the protector of their heresy, and the active agent of their most atrocious projects".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 4:11
verses.text: Such were the murders to which the blasphemy of Arius gave rise.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 4:12
verses.text: Their mad rage against the Only-begotten was matched by cruel deeds against His servants.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 5:1
verses.text: Chapter V.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 5:2
verses.text: —The Heresy of Macedonius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 5:3
verses.text: The Arians, having effected the death of Paulus, or rather having despatched him to the kingdom of heaven, promoted Macedonius in his place, who, they imagined, held the same sentiments, and belonged to the same faction as themselves, because he, like them, blasphemed the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 5:4
verses.text: But, shortly after, they deposed him also, because he refused to call Him a creature Whom the Holy Scriptures affirm to be the Son of God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 5:5
verses.text: After his separation from them, he became the leader of a sect of his own.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 5:6
verses.text: He taught that the Son of God is not of the same substance as the Father, but that He is like Him in every particular.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 5:7
verses.text: He also openly affirmed that the Holy Ghost is a creature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 5:8
verses.text: These circumstances occurred not long afterwards as we have narrated them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:1
verses.text: Chapter VI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:2
verses.text: —Council held at Sardica.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:3
verses.text: Two hundred and fifty bishops assembled at Sardica, as is proved by ancient records.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:4
verses.text: The great Athanasius, Asclepas, bishop of Gaza, already mentioned, and Marcellus, bishop of Ancyra, the metropolis of Galatia, who also held this bishopric at the time of the council of Nicaea, all repaired thither.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:5
verses.text: The calumniators, and the chiefs of the Arian faction, who had previously judged the cause of Athanasius, also attended.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:6
verses.text: But when they found that the members of the synod were staunch in their adherence to sound doctrine, they would not even enter the council, although they had been summoned to it, but fled away, both accusers and judges.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:7
verses.text: All these circumstances are far more clearly explained in a letter drawn up by the council; and I shall therefore now insert it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:8
verses.text: Synodical Letter from the Bishops assembled at Sardica, addressed to the other Bishops.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:9
verses.text: "The holy council assembled at Sardica, from Rome, Spain, Gaul, Italy, Campania, Calabria, Africa, Sardinia, Pannonia, Moesia, Dacia, Dardania, Lesser Dacia, Macedonia, Thessaly, Achaia, Epirus, Thrace, Rhodope, Asia, Caria, Bithynia, the Hellespont, Phrygia, Pisidia, Cappadocia, Pontus, the lesser Phrygia, Cilicia, Pamphylia, Lydia, the Cyclades, Egypt, the Thebaid, Libya, Galatia, Palestine and Arabia, to the bishops throughout the world, our fellow-ministers in the catholic and apostolic Church, and our beloved brethren in the Lord.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:10
verses.text: Peace be unto you.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:11
verses.text: "The madness of the Arians has often led them to the perpetration of violent atrocities against the servants of God who keep the true faith; they introduce false doctrines themselves, and persecute those who uphold orthodox principles.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:12
verses.text: So violent were their attacks on the faith, that they reached the ears of our most pious emperors.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:13
verses.text: Through the co-operation of the grace of God, the emperors have summoned us from different provinces and cities to the holy council which they have appointed to be held in the city of Sardica, in order that all dissensions may be terminated, all evil doctrines expelled, and the religion of Christ alone maintained amongst all people.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:14
verses.text: Some bishops from the east have attended the council at the solicitation of our most religious emperors, principally on account of the reports circulated against our beloved brethren and fellow-ministers, Athanasius, bishop of Alexandria, Marcellus, bishop of Ancyra in Galatia, and Asclepas, bishop of Gaza.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:15
verses.text: Perhaps the calumnies of the Arians have already reached you, and they have endeavoured thus to forestall the council, and make you believe their groundless accusations of the innocent, and prevent any suspicion being raised of the depraved heresy which they uphold.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:16
verses.text: But they have not long been permitted so to act.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:17
verses.text: The Lord is the Protector of the churches; for them and for us all He suffered death, and opened for us the way to heaven.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:18
verses.text: "The adherents of Eusebius, Maris, Theodorus, Theognis, Ursacius, Valens, Menophantus, and Stephanus, had already written to Julius, the bishop of Rome, and our fellow-minister, against our aforesaid fellow-ministers, Athanasius, bishop of Alexandria, Marcellus, bishop of Ancyra in Galatia, and Asclepas, bishop of Gaza.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:19
verses.text: Some bishops of the opposite party wrote also to Julius, testifying to the innocence of Athanasius, and proving that all that had been asserted by the followers of Eusebius was nothing more than lies and slander.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:20
verses.text: The refusal of the Arians to obey the summons of our beloved brother and fellow-ruler, Julius, and also the letter written by that bishop, clearly prove the falseness of their accusation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:21
verses.text: For, had they believed that what they had done and represented against our fellow-minister admitted of justification, they would have gone to Rome.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:22
verses.text: But their mode of procedure in this great and holy council is a manifest proof of their fraud.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:23
verses.text: Upon their arrival at Sardica, they perceived that our brethren, Athanasius, Marcellus, Asclepas, and others, were there also; they were therefore afraid to come to the test, although they had been summoned, not once or twice only, but repeatedly.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:24
verses.text: There were they waited for by the assembled bishops, particularly by the venerable Hosius, one worthy of all honour and respect, on account of his advanced age, his adherence to the faith, and his labours for the church.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:25
verses.text: All urged them to join the assembly and avail themselves of the opportunity of proving, in the presence of their fellow-ministers, the truth of the charges they had brought against them in their absence, both by word and by letter.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:26
verses.text: But they refused to obey the summons, as we have already stated, and so by their excesses proved the falsity of their statements, and all but proclaimed aloud the plot and schemes they had formed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:27
verses.text: Men confident of the truth of their assertions are always ready to stand to them openly.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:28
verses.text: But as these accusers would not appear to substantiate what they had advanced, any future allegations which they may by their usual artifices bring against our fellow-ministers, will only be regarded as proceeding from a desire of slandering them in their absence, without the courage to confront them openly.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:29
verses.text: "They fled, beloved brethren, not only because their charges were slander, but also because they saw men arrive with serious and manifold accusations against themselves.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:30
verses.text: Chains and fetters were produced.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:31
verses.text: Some were present whom they had exiled: others came forward as representatives of those still kept in exile.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:32
verses.text: There stood relations and friends of men whom they had put to death.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:33
verses.text: Most serious of all, bishops also appeared, one of whom exhibited the irons and the chains with which they had laden him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:34
verses.text: Others testified that death followed their false charges.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:35
verses.text: For their infatuation had led them so far as even to attempt the life of a bishop; and he would have been killed had he not escaped from their hands.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:36
verses.text: Theodulus, our fellow-minister, of blessed memory, passed hence with their calumny on his name; for, through it, he had been condemned to death.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:37
verses.text: Some showed the wounds which had been inflicted on them by the sword; others deposed that they had been exposed to the miseries of famine.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:38
verses.text: "All these depositions were made, not by a few obscure individuals, but by whole churches; the presbyters of these churches giving evidence that the persecutors had armed the military against them with swords, and the common people with clubs; had employed judicial threats, and produced spurious documents.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:39
verses.text: The letters written by Theognis, for the purpose of prejudicing the emperor against our fellow-ministers, Athanasius, Marcellus, and Asclepas, were read and attested by those who had formerly been the deacons of Theognis.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:40
verses.text: It was also proved that they had stripped virgins naked, had burnt churches, and imprisoned our fellow-ministers, and all because of the infamous heresy of the Ariomaniacs.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:41
verses.text: For thus all who refused to make common cause with them were treated.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:42
verses.text: "The consciousness of having committed all these crimes placed them in great straits.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:43
verses.text: Ashamed of their deeds, which could no longer be concealed, they repaired to Sardica, thinking that their boldness in venturing thither would remove all suspicion of their guilt.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:44
verses.text: But when they perceived the presence of those whom they had falsely accused, and of those who had suffered from their cruelty; and that likewise several had come with irrefragable accusations against them, they would not enter the council.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:45
verses.text: Our fellow-ministers, on the other hand, Athanasius, Marcellus, and Asclepas, took every means to induce them to attend, by tears, by urgency, by challenge, promising not only to prove the falsity of their accusations, but also to show how deeply they had injured their own churches.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:46
verses.text: But they were so overwhelmed by the consciousness of their own evil deeds, that they took to flight, and by this flight clearly proved the falsity of their accusations as well as their own guilt.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:47
verses.text: "But though their calumny and perfidy, which had indeed been apparent from the beginning, were now clearly perceived, yet we determined to examine the circumstances of the case according to the laws of truth, lest they should, from their very flight, derive pretexts for renewed acts of deceitfulness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:48
verses.text: "Upon carrying this resolution into effect, we proved by their actions that they were false accusers, and that they had formed plots against our fellow-ministers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:49
verses.text: Arsenius, whom they declared had been put to death by Athanasius, is still alive, and takes his place among the living.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:50
verses.text: This fact alone is sufficient to show that their other allegations are false.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:51
verses.text: "Although they spread a report everywhere that a chalice had been broken by Macarius, one of the presbyters of Athanasius, yet those who came from Alexandria, from Mareotis, and from other places, testified that this was not the fact; and the bishops in Egypt wrote to Julius, our fellow-minister, declaring that there was not the least suspicion that such a deed had been done.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:52
verses.text: The judicial facts which the Arians assert they possess against Macarius have been all drawn up by one party; and in these documents the depositions of pagans and of catechumens were included.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:53
verses.text: One of these catechumens, when interrogated, replied that he was in the church on the entry of Macarius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:54
verses.text: Another deposed that Ischyras, whom they had talked about so much, was then lying ill in his cell.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:55
verses.text: Hence it appears that the mysteries could not have been celebrated at that time, as the catechumens were present, and as Ischyras was absent; for he was at that very time confined by illness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:56
verses.text: Ischyras, that wicked man who had falsely affirmed that Athanasius had burnt some of the sacred books, and had been convicted of the crime, now confessed that he was ill in bed when Macarius arrived; hence the falsehood of his accusation was clearly demonstrated.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:57
verses.text: His calumny was, however, rewarded by his party; they gave him the title of a bishop, although he was not yet even a presbyter.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:58
verses.text: For two presbyters came to the synod, who some time back had been attached to Meletius, and were afterwards received back by the blessed Alexander, bishop of Alexandria, and are now with Athanasius, protesting that he had never been ordained a presbyter, and that Meletius had never had any church, or employed any minister in Mareotis.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:59
verses.text: Yet, although he had never been ordained a presbyter, they promote him to a bishopric, in order that his title may impose upon those who hear his false accusations.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:60
verses.text: "The writings of our fellow-minister, Marcellus, were also read, and plainly evinced the duplicity of the adherents of Eusebius; for what Marcellus had simply suggested as a point of inquiry, they accused him of professing as a point of faith.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:61
verses.text: The statements which he had made, both before and after the inquiry, were read, and his faith was proved to be orthodox.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:62
verses.text: He did not affirm, as they represented, that the beginning of the Word of God was dated from His conception by the holy Mary, or that His kingdom would have an end.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:63
verses.text: On the contrary, he wrote that His kingdom had had no beginning, and would have no end.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:64
verses.text: Asclepas, our fellow-minister, produced the reports drawn up at Antioch in the presence of the accusers, and of Eusebius, bishop of Caesarea, and proved his innocence by the sentence of the bishops who had presided as judges.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:65
verses.text: "It was not then without cause, beloved brethren, that, although so frequently summoned, they would not attend the council; it was not without cause that they took to flight.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:66
verses.text: The reproaches of conscience constrained them to make their escape, and thus, at the same time, to demonstrate the groundlessness of their calumnies, and the truth of those accusations which were advanced and proved against them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:67
verses.text: Besides all the other grounds of complaint, it may be added that all those who had been accused of holding the Arian heresy, and had been ejected in consequence, were not only received, but advanced to the highest dignities by them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:68
verses.text: They raised deacons to the presbyterate, and thence to the episcopate; and in all this they were actuated by no other motive than the desire of propagating and diffusing their heresy, and of corrupting the true faith.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:69
verses.text: "Next to Eusebius, the following are their principal leaders; Theodorus, bishop of Heraclea, Narcissus, bishop of Neronias in Cilicia, Stephanus, bishop of Antioch, Georgius, bishop of Laodicea, Acacius, bishop of Caesarea in Palestine, Menophantus, bishop of Ephesus in Asia, Ursacius, bishop of Singidunum in Moesia, and Valens, bishop of Mursa in Pannonia.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:70
verses.text: These bishops forbade those who came with them from the east to attend the holy council, or to unite with the Church of God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:71
verses.text: On their road to Sardica they held private assemblies at different places, and formed a compact cemented by threats, that, when they arrived in Sardica, they would not join the holy council, nor assist at its deliberations; arranging that, as soon as they had arrived they should present themselves for form's sake, and forthwith betake themselves to flight.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:72
verses.text: These facts were made known to us by our fellow-ministers, Macarius of Palestine, and Asterius of Arabia, who came with them to Sardica, but refused to share their unorthodoxy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:73
verses.text: These bishops complained before the holy council of the violent treatment they had received from them, and of the want of right principles evinced in all their transactions.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:74
verses.text: They added that there were many amongst them who still held orthodox opinions, but that these were prevented from going to the council; and that sometimes threats, sometimes promises, were resorted to, in order to retain them in that party.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:75
verses.text: For this reason they were compelled to reside together in one house; and never allowed, even for the shortest space of time, to be alone.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:76
verses.text: "It is not right to pass over in silence and without rebuke the calumnies, the imprisonments, the murders, the stripes, the forged letters, the indignities, the stripping naked of virgins, the banishments, the destruction of churches, the acts of incendiarism, the translation of bishops from small towns to large dioceses, and above all, the ill-starred Arian heresy, raised by their means against the true faith.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:77
verses.text: For these causes, therefore, we declare the innocence and purity of our beloved brethren and fellow-ministers, Athanasius, bishop of Alexandria, Marcellus, bishop of Ancyra in Galatia, and Asclepas, bishop of Gaza, and of all the other servants of God who are with them; and we have written to each of their dioceses, in order that the people of each church may be made acquainted with the innocence of their respective bishops, and that they may recognise them alone and wait for their return.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:78
verses.text: Men who have come down on their churches like wolves, such as Gregorius in Alexandria, Basilius in Ancyra, and Quintianus in Gaza, we charge them not even to call bishops, nor yet Christians, nor to have any communion with them, nor to receive any letters from them, nor to write to them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:79
verses.text: "Theodorus, bishop of Heraclea in Europe, Narcissus, bishop of Neronias in Cilicia, Acacius, bishop of Caesarea in Palestine, Stephanus, bishop of Antioch, Ursacius, bishop of Singidunum in Moesia, Valens, bishop of Mursa in Pannonia, Menophantus, bishop of Ephesus, and Georgius, bishop of Laodicea (for though fear kept him from leaving the East, he has been deposed by the blessed Alexander, bishop of Alexandria, and has imbibed the infatuation of the Arians), have on account of their various crimes been cast forth from their bishoprics by the unanimous decision of the holy council.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:80
verses.text: We have decreed that they are not only not to be regarded as bishops, but to be refused communion with us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:81
verses.text: For those who separate the Son from the substance and divinity of the Father, and alienate the Word from the Father, ought to be separated from the Catholic Church, and alienated from all who bear the name of Christians.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:82
verses.text: Let them then be anathema to you, and to all the faithful, because they have corrupted the word of truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:83
verses.text: For the apostle's precept enjoins, if any one should bring to you another gospel than that which ye have received, let him be accursed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:84
verses.text: Command that no one hold communion with them; for light can have no fellowship with darkness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:85
verses.text: Keep far off from them; for what concord has Christ with Belial? Be careful, beloved brethren, that you neither write to them nor receive their letters.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:86
verses.text: Endeavour, beloved brethren and fellow-ministers, as though present with us in spirit at the council, to give your hearty consent to what is enacted, and affix to it your written signature, for the sake of preserving unanimity of opinion among all our fellow-ministers throughout the world.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:87
verses.text: "We declare those men excommunicate from the Catholic Church who say that Christ is God, but not the true God; that He is the Son, but not the true Son; and that He is both begotten and made; for such persons acknowledge that they understand by the term 'begotten,' that which has been made; and because, although the Son of God existed before all ages, they attribute to Him, who exists not in time but before all time, a beginning and an end.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:88
verses.text: "Valens and Ursacius have, like two vipers brought forth by an asp, proceeded from the Arian heresy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:89
verses.text: For they boastingly declare themselves to be undoubted Christians, and yet affirm that the Word and the Holy Ghost were both crucified and slain, and that they died and rose again; and they pertinaciously maintain, like the heretics, that the Father, the Son, and the Holy Ghost are of diverse and distinct essences.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:90
verses.text: We have been taught, and we hold the catholic and apostolic tradition and faith and confession which teach, that the Father, the Son, and the Holy Ghost have one essence, which is termed substance by the heretics.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:91
verses.text: If it is asked, 'What is the essence of the Son?' we confess, that it is that which is acknowledged to be that of the Father alone; for the Father has never been, nor could ever be, without the Son, nor the Son without the Father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:92
verses.text: It is most absurd to affirm that the Father ever existed without the Son, for that this could never be so has been testified by the Son Himself, who said, 'I am in the Father, and the Father in Me;' and 'I and My Father are one.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:93
verses.text: ' None of us denies that He was begotten; but we say that He was begotten before all things, whether visible or invisible; and that He is the Creator of archangels and angels, and of the world, and of the human race.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:94
verses.text: It is written, 'Wisdom which is the worker of all things taught me,' and again, 'All things were made by Him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:95
verses.text: '  "He could not have existed always if He had had a beginning, for the everlasting Word has no beginning, and God will never have an end.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:96
verses.text: We do not say that the Father is Son, nor that the Son is Father; but that the Father is Father, and the Son of the Father Son.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:97
verses.text: We confess that the Son is Power of the Father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:98
verses.text: We confess that the Word is Word of God the Father, and that beside Him there is no other.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:99
verses.text: We believe the Word to be the true God, and Wisdom and Power.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:100
verses.text: We affirm that He is truly the Son, yet not in the way in which others are said to be sons: for they are either gods by reason of their regeneration, or are called sons of God on account of their merit, and not on account of their being of one essence, as is the case with the Father and the Son.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:101
verses.text: We confess an Only-begotten and a Firstborn; but that the Word is only-begotten, who ever was and is in the Father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:102
verses.text: We use the word firstborn with respect to His human nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:103
verses.text: But He is superior (to man) in the new creation (of the Resurrection), inasmuch as He is the Firstborn from the dead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:104
verses.text: "We confess that God is; we confess the divinity of the Father and of the Son to be one.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:105
verses.text: No one denies that the Father is greater than the Son: not on account of another essence, nor yet on account of their difference, but simply from the very name of the Father being greater than that of the Son.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:106
verses.text: The words uttered by our Lord, 'I and My Father are one,' are by those men explained as referring to the concord and harmony which prevail between the Father and the Son; but this is a blasphemous and perverse interpretation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:107
verses.text: We, as Catholics, unanimously condemned this foolish and lamentable opinion: for just as mortal men on a difference having arisen between them quarrel and afterwards are reconciled, so do such interpreters say that disputes and dissension are liable to arise between God the Father Almighty and His Son; a supposition which is altogether absurd and untenable.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:108
verses.text: But we believe and maintain that those holy words, 'I and My Father are one,' point out the oneness of essence which is one and the same in the Father and in the Son.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:109
verses.text: "We also believe that the Son reigns with the Father, that His reign has neither beginning nor end, and that it is not bounded by time, nor can ever cease: for that which always exists never begins to be, and can never cease.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:110
verses.text: "We believe in and we receive the Holy Ghost the Comforter, whom the Lord both promised and sent.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:111
verses.text: We believe in It as sent.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:112
verses.text: "It was not the Holy Ghost who suffered, but the manhood with which He clothed Himself; which He took from the Virgin Mary, which being man was capable of suffering; for man is mortal, whereas God is immortal.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:113
verses.text: We believe that on the third day He rose, the man in God, not God in the man; and that He brought as a gift to His Father the manhood which He had delivered from sin and corruption.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:114
verses.text: "We believe that, at a meet and fixed time, He Himself will judge all men and all their deeds.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:115
verses.text: "So great is the ignorance and mental darkness of those whom we have mentioned, that they are unable to see the light of truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:116
verses.text: They cannot comprehend the meaning of the words: 'that they may be one in us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:117
verses.text: ' It is obvious why the word 'one' was used; it was because the apostles received the Holy Spirit of God, and yet there were none amongst them who were the Spirit, neither was there any one of them who was Word, Wisdom, Power, or Only-begotten.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:118
verses.text: 'As Thou,' He said, 'and I are one, that they, may be one in us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:119
verses.text: ' These holy words, 'that they may be one in us,' are strictly accurate: for the Lord did not say, 'one in the same way that I and the Father are one,' but He said, 'that the disciples, being knit together and united, may be one in faith and in confession, and so in the grace and piety of God the Father, and by the indulgence and love of our Lord Jesus Christ, may be able to become one.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:120
verses.text: '"  From this letter may be learnt the duplicity of the calumniators, and the injustice of the former judges, as well as the soundness of the decrees.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:121
verses.text: These holy fathers have taught us not only truths respecting the Divine nature, but also the doctrine of the Incarnation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:122
verses.text: Constans was much concerned on hearing of the easy temper of his brother, and was highly incensed against those who had contrived this plot and artfully taken advantage of it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:123
verses.text: He chose two of the bishops who had attended the council of Sardica, and sent them with letters to his brother; he also despatched Salianus, a military commander who was celebrated for his piety and integrity, on the same embassy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:124
verses.text: The letters which he forwarded by them, and which were worthy of himself, contained not only entreaties and counsels, but also menaces.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:125
verses.text: In the first place, he charged his brother to attend to all that the bishops might say, and to take cognizance of the crimes of Stephanus and of his accomplices.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:126
verses.text: He also required him to restore Athanasius to his flock; the calumny of the accusers and the injustice and ill-will of his former judges having become evident.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:127
verses.text: He added, that if he would not accede to his request, and perform this act of justice, he would himself go to Alexandria, restore Athanasius to his flock which earnestly longed for him, and expel all opponents.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 6:128
verses.text: Constantius was at Antioch when he received this letter; and he agreed to carry out all that his brother commanded.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 7:1
verses.text: Chapter VII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 7:2
verses.text: —Account of the Bishops Euphratas and Vincentius, and of the plot formed in Antioch against them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 7:3
verses.text: The wonted opponents of the truth were so much displeased at these proceedings, that they planned a notoriously execrable and impious crime.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 7:4
verses.text: The two bishops resided near the foot of the mountain, while the military commander had settled in a lodging in another quarter.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 7:5
verses.text: At this period Stephanus held the rudder of the church of Antioch, and had well nigh sunk the ship, for he employed several tools in his despotic doings, and by their aid involved all who maintained orthodox doctrines in manifold calamities.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 7:6
verses.text: The leader of these instruments was a young man of a rash and reckless character, who led a very infamous life.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 7:7
verses.text: He not only dragged away men from the market-place, and treated them with blows and insult, but had the audacity to enter private houses, whence he carried off men and women of irreproachable character.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 7:8
verses.text: But, not to be too prolix in relating his crimes, I will merely narrate his daring conduct towards the bishops; for this alone is sufficient to give an idea of the unlawful deeds of violence which he perpetrated against the citizens.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 7:9
verses.text: He went to one of the lowest women of the town, and told her that some strangers had just arrived, who desired to pass the night with her.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 7:10
verses.text: He took fifteen of his band, placed them in hiding among the stone walls at the bottom of the hill, and then went for the prostitute.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 7:11
verses.text: After giving the preconcerted signal, and learning that the folk privy to the plot were on the spot, he went to the gate of the courtyard belonging to the inn where the bishops were lodging.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 7:12
verses.text: The doors were opened by one of the household servants, who had been bribed by him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 7:13
verses.text: He then conducted the woman into the house, pointed out to her the door of the room where one of the bishops slept, and desired her to enter.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 7:14
verses.text: Then he went out to call his accomplices.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 7:15
verses.text: The door which he had pointed out happened to be that of Euphratas, the elder bishop, whose room was the outer of the two.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 7:16
verses.text: Vincentius, the other bishop, occupied the inner room.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 7:17
verses.text: When the woman entered the room of Euphratas, he heard the sound of her footsteps, and, as it was then dark, asked who was there.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 7:18
verses.text: She spoke, and Euphratas was full of alarm, for he thought that it was a devil imitating the voice of a woman, and he called upon Christ the Saviour for aid.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 7:19
verses.text: Onager, for this was the name of the leader of this wicked band (a name peculiarly appropriate to him, as he not only used his hands but also his feet as weapons against the pious), had in the meantime returned with his lawless crew, denouncing as criminals those who were expecting to be judges of crime themselves.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 7:20
verses.text: At the noise which was made all the servants came running in, and up got Vincentius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 7:21
verses.text: They closed the gate of the courtyards, and captured seven of the gang; but Onager and the rest made off.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 7:22
verses.text: The woman was committed to custody with those who had been seized.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 7:23
verses.text: At the break of day the bishops awoke the officer who had come with them, and they all three proceeded together to the palace, to complain of the audacious acts of Stephanus, whose evil deeds, they said, were too evident to need either trial or torture to prove them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 7:24
verses.text: The general loudly demanded of the emperor that the audacious act should not be dealt with synodically, but by ordinary legal process, and offered to give up the clergy attached to the bishops to be first examined, and declared that the agents of Stephanus must undergo the torture too.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 7:25
verses.text: To this Stephanus insolently objected, alleging that the clergy ought not to be scourged.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 7:26
verses.text: The emperor and the principal authorities then decided that it would be better to judge the cause in the palace.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 7:27
verses.text: The woman was first of all questioned, and was asked by whom she was conducted to the inn where the bishops were lodging.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 7:28
verses.text: She replied, that a young man came to her, and told her that some strangers had arrived who were desirous of her company; that in the evening he conducted her to the inn; that he went to look for his band, and when he had found it, brought her in through the door of the court, and desired her to go into the chamber adjoining the vestibule.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 7:29
verses.text: She added, that the bishop asked who was there; that he was alarmed; and that he began to pray; and that then others ran to the spot.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 8:1
verses.text: Chapter VIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 8:2
verses.text: —Stephanus Deposed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 8:3
verses.text: After the judges had heard these replies, they ordered the youngest of those who had been arrested to be brought before them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 8:4
verses.text: Before he was subjected to the examination by scourging, he confessed the whole plot, and stated that it was planned and carried into execution by Onager.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 8:5
verses.text: On this latter being brought in he affirmed that he had only acted according to the commands of Stephanus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 8:6
verses.text: The guilt of Stephanus being thus demonstrated, the bishops then present were charged to depose him, and expel him from the Church.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 8:7
verses.text: By his expulsion the Church was not, however, wholly freed from the plague of Arianism.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 8:8
verses.text: Leontius, who succeeded him in his presidency, was a Phrygian of so subtle and artful a disposition, that he might be said to resemble the sunken rocks of the sea.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 8:9
verses.text: We shall presently narrate more concerning him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 9:1
verses.text: Chapter IX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 9:2
verses.text: —The Second Return of Saint Athanasius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 9:3
verses.text: The emperor Constantius, having become acquainted with the plots formed against the bishops, wrote to the great Athanasius once, and twice, aye and thrice, exhorting him to return from the West.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 9:4
verses.text: I shall here insert the second letter, because it is the shortest of the three.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 9:5
verses.text: Constantius Augustus the Conqueror to Athanasius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 9:6
verses.text: "Although I have already apprised you by previous letters, that you can, without fear of molestation, return to our court, in order that you may, according to my ardent desire, be reinstated in your own bishopric, yet I now again despatch another letter to your gravity to exhort you to take immediately, without fear or suspicion, a public vehicle and return to us, in order that you may receive all that you desire".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 9:7
verses.text: When Athanasius returned, Constantius received him with kindness, and bade him go back to the Church of Alexandria.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 9:8
verses.text: But there were some attached to the court, infected with the errors of Arianism, who maintained that Athanasius ought to cede one church to those who were unwilling to hold communion with him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 9:9
verses.text: On this being mentioned to the emperor, and by the emperor to Athanasius, he remarked, that the imperial command appeared to be just; but that he also wished to make a request.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 9:10
verses.text: The emperor readily promising to grant him whatever he might ask, he said that those in Antioch who objected to hold communion with the party now in possession of the churches wanted temples to pray in, and that it was only fair that one House of God also be assigned to them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 9:11
verses.text: This request was deemed just and reasonable by the emperor; but the leaders of the Arian faction resisted its being carried into execution, maintaining that neither party ought to have the churches assigned to them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 9:12
verses.text: Constantius on this was struck with high admiration for Athanasius, and sent him back to Alexandria.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 9:13
verses.text: Gregorius was dead, having met his end at the hands of the Alexandrians themselves.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 9:14
verses.text: The people kept high holiday in honour of their pastor; feasting marked their joy at seeing him again, and praise was given to God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 9:15
verses.text: Not long after Constans departed this life.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 10:1
verses.text: Chapter X.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 10:2
verses.text: —Third exile and flight of Athanasius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 10:3
verses.text: Those who had obtained entire ascendency over the mind of Constantius, and influenced him as they pleased, reminded him that Athanasius had been the cause of the differences between his brother and himself, which had nearly led to the rupture of the bonds of nature, and the kindling of a civil war.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 10:4
verses.text: Constantius was induced by these representations not only to banish, but also to condemn the holy Athanasius to death; and he accordingly despatched Sebastianus, a military commander, with a very large body of soldiery to slay him, as if he had been a criminal.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 10:5
verses.text: How the one led the attack and the other escaped will be best told in the words of him who so suffered and was so wonderfully saved.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 10:6
verses.text: Thus Athanasius writes in his Apology for his Flight:—"Let the circumstances of my retreat be investigated, and the testimony of the opposite faction be collected; for Arians accompanied the soldiers, as well for the purpose of spurring them on, as of pointing me out to those who did not know me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 10:7
verses.text: If they are not touched with sympathy at the tale I tell, at least let them listen in the silence of shame.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 10:8
verses.text: It was night, and some of the people were keeping vigil, for a communion was expected.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 10:9
verses.text: A body of soldiers suddenly advanced upon them, consisting of a general and five thousand armed men with naked swords, bows and arrows, and clubs, as I have already stated.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 10:10
verses.text: The general surrounded the church, posting his men in close order, that those within might be prevented from going out.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 10:11
verses.text: I deemed that I ought not in such a time of confusion to leave the people, but that I ought rather to be the first to meet the danger; so I sat down on my throne and desired the deacon to read a psalm, and the people to respond, 'For His mercy endureth for ever.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 10:12
verses.text: ' Then I bade them all return to their own houses.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 10:13
verses.text: But now the general with the soldiery forced his way into the church, and surrounded the sanctuary in order to arrest me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 10:14
verses.text: The clergy and the laity who had remained clamorously besought me to withdraw.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 10:15
verses.text: This I firmly refused to do until all the others had retreated.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 10:16
verses.text: I rose, had a prayer offered, and directed all the people to retire.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 10:17
verses.text: 'It is better,' said I, 'for me to meet the danger alone, than for any of you to be hurt.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 10:18
verses.text: ' When the greater number of the people had left the church, and just as the rest were following, the monks and some of the clergy who had remained came up and drew me out.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 10:19
verses.text: And so, may the truth be my witness, the Lord leading and protecting me, we passed through the midst of the soldiers, some of whom were stationed around the sanctuary, and others marching about the church.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 10:20
verses.text: Thus I went out unperceived, and fervently thanked God that I had not abandoned the people, but that after they had been sent away in safety, I had been enabled to escape from the hands of those who sought my life".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 11:1
verses.text: Chapter XI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 11:2
verses.text: —The evil and daring deeds done by Georgius in Alexandria.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 11:3
verses.text: Athanasius having thus escaped the bloodstained hands of his adversaries, Georgius, who was truly another wolf, was entrusted with authority over the flock.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 11:4
verses.text: He treated the sheep with more cruelty than wolf, or bear, or leopard could have shewn.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 11:5
verses.text: He compelled young women who had vowed perpetual virginity, not only to disown the communion of Athanasius, but also to anathematize the faith of the fathers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 11:6
verses.text: The agent in his cruelty was Sebastianus, an officer in command of troops.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 11:7
verses.text: He ordered a fire to be kindled in the centre of the city, and placed the virgins, who were stripped naked, close to it, commanding them to deny the faith.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 11:8
verses.text: Although they formed a most sorrowful and pitiable spectacle for believers as well as for unbelievers, they considered that all these dishonours conferred the highest honour on them; and they joyfully received the blows inflicted on them on account of their faith.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 11:9
verses.text: All these facts shall be more clearly narrated by their own pastor.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 11:10
verses.text: "About Lent, Georgius returned from Cappadocia, and added to the evils which he had been taught by our enemies.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 11:11
verses.text: After the Easter week virgins were cast into prison, bishops were bound and dragged away by the soldiers, the homes of widows and of orphans were pillaged, robbery and violence went on from house to house, and the Christians during the darkness of night were seized and torn away from their dwellings.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 11:12
verses.text: Seals were fixed on many houses.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 11:13
verses.text: The brothers of the clergy were in peril for their brothers' sake.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 11:14
verses.text: These cruelties were very atrocious, but still more so were those which were subsequently perpetrated.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 11:15
verses.text: In the week following the holy festival of Pentecost, the people who were keeping a fast came out to the cemetery to pray, because they all renounced any communion with Georgius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 11:16
verses.text: This vilest of men was informed of this circumstance, and he incited Sebastianus the military commander, a Manichean, to attack the people; and, accordingly, on the Lord's day itself he rushed upon them with a large body of armed soldiers wielding naked swords, and bows, and arrows.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 11:17
verses.text: He found but few Christians in the act of praying, for most of them had retired on account of the lateness of the hour.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 11:18
verses.text: Then he did such deeds as might be expected from one who had lent his ears to such teachers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 11:19
verses.text: He ordered a large fire to be lighted, and the virgins to be brought close to it, and then tried to compel them to declare themselves of the Arian creed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 11:20
verses.text: When he perceived that they were conquering, and giving no heed to the fire, he ordered them to be stripped naked, and to be beaten until their faces for a long while were scarcely recognisable.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 11:21
verses.text: He then seized forty men, and inflicted on them a new kind of torture.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 11:22
verses.text: He ordered them to be scourged with branches of palm-trees, retaining their thorns; and by these their flesh was so lacerated that some because of the thorns fixed fast in them had again and again to put themselves under the surgeon's hand; others were not able to bear the agony and died.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 11:23
verses.text: All who survived, and also the virgins, were then banished to the Greater Oasis.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 11:24
verses.text: They even refused to give up the bodies of the dead to their kinsfolk for burial, but flung them away unburied, and hid them just as they pleased, in order that it might appear that they had nothing to do with these cruel transactions, and were ignorant of them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 11:25
verses.text: But they were deceived in this foolish expectation: for the friends of the slain, while they rejoiced at the faithfulness of the deceased, deeply lamented the loss of the corpses, and spread abroad a full account of the cruelty that had been perpetrated.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 11:26
verses.text: "The following bishops were banished from Egypt and from Libya:—Ammonius, Muïus, Caius, Philo, Hermes, Plenius, Psinosiris, Nilammon, Agapius, Anagamphus, Marcus, Dracontius, Adelphius, another Ammonius, another Marcus, and Athenodorus; and also the presbyters Hierax and Dioscorus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 11:27
verses.text: These were all driven into exile in so cruel a manner that many died on the road, and others at the place of their banishment.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 11:28
verses.text: The persecutors caused the death of more than thirty bishops.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 11:29
verses.text: For, like Ahab, their mind was set on rooting out the truth, had it been possible".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 11:30
verses.text: Athanasius also, in a letter addressed to the virgins who were treated with so much barbarity, uses the following words: "Let none of you be grieved although these impious heretics grudge you burial and prevent your corpses being carried forth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 11:31
verses.text: The impiety of the Arians has reached such a height, that they block up the gates, and sit like so many demons around the tombs, in order to hinder the dead from being interred".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 11:32
verses.text: These and many other similar atrocities were perpetrated by Georgius in Alexandria.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 11:33
verses.text: The holy Athanasius was well aware that there was no spot which could be considered a place of safety for him; for the emperor had promised a very large reward to whoever should bring him alive, or his head as a proof of his death.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 12:1
verses.text: Chapter XII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 12:2
verses.text: —Council of Milan.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 12:3
verses.text: After the death of Constans, Magnentius assumed the chief authority over the Western empire; and, to repress his usurpation, Constantius repaired to Europe.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 12:4
verses.text: But this war, severe as it was, did not put an end to the war against the Church.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 12:5
verses.text: Constantius, who had embraced Arian tenets and readily yielded to the influence of others, was persuaded to convoke a council at Milan, a city of Italy, and first to compel all the assembled bishops to sign the deposition enacted by the iniquitous judges at Tyre; and then, since Athanasius had been expelled from the Church, to draw up another confession of faith.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 12:6
verses.text: The bishops assembled in council on the receipt of the imperial letter, but they were far from acting according to its directions.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 12:7
verses.text: On the contrary, they told the emperor to his face that what he had commanded was unjust and impious.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 12:8
verses.text: For this act of courage they were expelled from the Church, and relegated to the furthest boundaries of the empire.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 12:9
verses.text: The admirable Athanasius thus mentions this circumstance in his Apology:—"Who," he writes, "can narrate such atrocities as they have perpetrated? A short time ago when the Churches were in the enjoyment of peace, and when the people were assembled for prayer, Liberius, bishop of Rome, Paulinus, bishop of the metropolis of Gaul, Dionysius, bishop of the metropolis of Italy, Luciferus, bishop of the metropolis of the Isles of Sardinia, and Eusebius, bishop of one of the cities of Italy, who were all exemplary bishops and preachers of the truth, were seized and driven into exile, for no other cause than because they could not assent to the Arian heresy, nor sign the false accusation which had been framed against us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 12:10
verses.text: It is unnecessary that I should speak of the great Hosius, that aged and faithful confessor of the faith, for every one knows that he also was sent into banishment.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 12:11
verses.text: Of all the bishops he is the most illustrious.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 12:12
verses.text: What council can be mentioned in which he did not preside, and convince all present by the power of his reasoning? What Church does not still retain the glorious memorials of his protection? Did any one ever go to him sorrowing, and not leave him rejoicing? Who ever asked his aid, and did not obtain all that he desired? Yet they had the boldness to attack this great man, simply because, from his knowledge of the impiety of their calumnies, he refused to affix his signature to their artful accusations against us".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 12:13
verses.text: From the above narrative will be seen the violence of the Arians against these holy men.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 12:14
verses.text: Athanasius also gives in the same book an account of the numerous plots formed by the chiefs of the Arian faction against many others:—"Did any one," said he, "whom they persecuted and got into their power ever escape from them without suffering what injuries they pleased to inflict? Was any one who was an object of their search found by them whom they did not subject to the most agonizing death, or else to the mutilation of all his limbs? The sentences inflicted by the judges are all attributable to these heretics; for the judges are but the agents of their will, and of their malice.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 12:15
verses.text: Where is there a place which contains no memorial of their atrocities? If any one ever differed from them in opinion, did they not, like Jezebel, falsely accuse and oppress him? Where is there a church which has not been plunged in sorrow by their plots against its bishop? Antioch has to mourn the loss of Eustathius, the faithful and the orthodox.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 12:16
verses.text: Balaneae weeps for Euphration; Paltus and Antaradus for Cymatius and Carterius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 12:17
verses.text: Adrianople has been called to deplore the loss of the well-beloved Eutropius, and of Lucius his successor, who was repeatedly loaded with chains, and expired beneath their weight.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 12:18
verses.text: Ancyra, Beroea, and Gaza had to mourn the absence of Marcellus, Cyrus and Asclepas, who, after having suffered much ill-treatment from this deceitful sect, were driven into exile.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 12:19
verses.text: Messengers were sent in quest of Theodulus and Olympius, bishops of Thrace, as well as of me and of the presbyters of my diocese; and had they found us, we should no doubt have been put to death.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 12:20
verses.text: But at the very time that they were planning our destruction we effected our escape, although they had sent letters to Donatus, the proconsul, against Olympius, and to Philagrius, against me".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 12:21
verses.text: Such were the audacious acts of this impious faction against the most holy Christians.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 12:22
verses.text: Hosius was the bishop of Cordova, and was the most highly distinguished of all those who assembled at the council of Nicaea; he also obtained the first place among those convened at Sardica.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 12:23
verses.text: I now desire to insert in my history an account of the admirable arguments addressed by the far-famed Liberius, in defence of the truth, to the emperor Constantius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 12:24
verses.text: They are recorded by some of the pious men of that period in order to stimulate others to the exercise of similar zeal in divine things.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 12:25
verses.text: Liberius had succeeded Julius, the successor of Silvester, in the government of the church of Rome.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:1
verses.text: Chapter XIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:2
verses.text: —Conference between Liberius, Pope of Rome, and the Emperor Constantius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:3
verses.text: Constantius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:4
verses.text: —"We have judged it right, as you are a Christian and the bishop of our city, to send for you in order to admonish you to abjure all connexion with the folly of the impious Athanasius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:5
verses.text: For when he was separated from the communion of the Church by the synod the whole world approved of the decision".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:6
verses.text: Liberius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:7
verses.text: —"O Emperor, ecclesiastical sentences ought to be enacted with strictest justice: therefore, if it be pleasing to your piety, order the court to be assembled, and if it be seen that Athanasius deserves condemnation, then let sentence be passed upon him according to ecclesiastical forms.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:8
verses.text: For it is not possible for us to condemn a man unheard and untried".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:9
verses.text: Constantius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:10
verses.text: —"The whole world has condemned his impiety; but he, as he has done from the first, laughs at the danger".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:11
verses.text: Liberius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:12
verses.text: —"Those who signed the condemnation were not eye-witnesses of anything that occurred; but were actuated by the desire of glory, and by the fear of disgrace at thy hands".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:13
verses.text: The Emperor.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:14
verses.text: —"What do you mean by glory and fear and disgrace?"  Liberius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:15
