verses.text: —"Those who love not the glory of God, but who attach greater value to thy gifts, have condemned a man whom they have neither seen nor judged; this is very contrary to the principles of Christians".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:16
verses.text: The Emperor.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:17
verses.text: —"Athanasius was tried in person at the council of Tyre, and all the bishops of the world at that synod condemned him".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:18
verses.text: Liberius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:19
verses.text: —"No judgment has ever been passed on him in his presence.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:20
verses.text: Those who there assembled condemned him after he had retired".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:21
verses.text: {{small-caps|Eusebius the Eunuch foolishly interposed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:22
verses.text: —"It was demonstrated at the council of Nicaea that he held opinions entirely at variance with the catholic faith".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:23
verses.text: Liberius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:24
verses.text: —"Of all those who sailed to Mareotis, and who were sent for the purpose of drawing up memorials against the accused, five only delivered the sentence against him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:25
verses.text: Of the five who were thus sent, two are now dead, namely, Theognis and Theodorus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:26
verses.text: The three others, Maris, Valens, and Ursacius, are still living.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:27
verses.text: Sentence was passed at Sardica against all those who were sent for this purpose to Mareotis.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:28
verses.text: They presented a petition to the council soliciting pardon for having drawn up at Mareotis memorials against Athanasius, consisting of false accusations and depositions of only one party.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:29
verses.text: Their petition is still in our hands.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:30
verses.text: Whose cause are we to espouse, O Emperor? With whom are we to agree and hold communion? With those who first condemned Athanasius, and then solicited pardon for having condemned him, or with those who have condemned these latter?"  Epictetus the Bishop.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:31
verses.text: —"O Emperor, it is not on behalf of the faith, nor in defence of ecclesiastical judgments that Liberius is pleading; but merely in order that he may boast before the Roman senators of having conquered the emperor in argument".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:32
verses.text: The Emperor (addressing Liberius).

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:33
verses.text: —"What portion do you constitute of the universe, that you alone by yourself take part with an impious man, and are destroying the peace of the empire and of the whole world?"  Liberius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:34
verses.text: —"My standing alone does not make the truth a whit the weaker.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:35
verses.text: According to the ancient story, there are found but three men resisting a decree".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:36
verses.text: Eusebius the Eunuch.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:37
verses.text: —"You make our emperor a Nebuchadnezzar".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:38
verses.text: Liberius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:39
verses.text: —"By no means.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:40
verses.text: But you rashly condemn a man without any trial.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:41
verses.text: What I desire is, in the first place, that a general confession of faith be signed, confirming that drawn up at the council of Nicaea.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:42
verses.text: And secondly, that all our brethren be recalled from exile, and reinstated in their own bishoprics.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:43
verses.text: If, when all this has been carried into execution, it can be shown that the doctrines of all those who now fill the churches with trouble are conformable to the apostolic faith, then we will all assemble at Alexandria to meet the accused, the accusers, and their defender, and after having examined the cause, we will pass judgment upon it".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:44
verses.text: Epictetus the Bishop.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:45
verses.text: —"There will not be sufficient post-carriages to convey so many bishops".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:46
verses.text: Liberius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:47
verses.text: —"Ecclesiastical affairs can be transacted without post-carriages.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:48
verses.text: The churches are able to provide means for the conveyance of their respective bishops to the sea coast".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:49
verses.text: The Emperor.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:50
verses.text: —"The sentence which has once been passed ought not to be revoked.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:51
verses.text: The decision of the greater number of bishops ought to prevail.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:52
verses.text: You alone retain friendship towards that impious man".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:53
verses.text: Liberius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:54
verses.text: —"O Emperor, it is a thing hitherto unheard of, that a judge should accuse the absent of impiety, as if he were his personal enemy".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:55
verses.text: The Emperor.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:56
verses.text: —"All without exception have been injured by him, but none so deeply as I have been.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:57
verses.text: Not content with the death of my eldest brother, he never ceased to excite Constans, of blessed memory, to enmity against me; but I, with much moderation, put up alike with the vehemence of both the instigator and his victim.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:58
verses.text: Not one of the victories which I have gained, not even excepting those over Magnentius and Silvanus, equals the ejection of this vile man from the government of the Church".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:59
verses.text: Liberius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:60
verses.text: —"Do not vindicate your own hatred and revenge, O Emperor, by the instrumentality of bishops; for their hands ought only to be raised for purposes of blessing and of sanctification.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:61
verses.text: If it be consonant with your will, command the bishops to return to their own residences; and if it appear that they are of one mind with him who to-day maintains the true doctrines of the confession of faith signed at Nicaea, then let them come together and see to the peace of the world, in order that an innocent man may not serve as a mark for reproach".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:62
verses.text: The Emperor.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:63
verses.text: —"One question only requires to be made.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:64
verses.text: I wish you to enter into communion with the churches, and to send you back to Rome.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:65
verses.text: Consent therefore to peace, and sign your assent, and then you shall return to Rome".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:66
verses.text: Liberius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:67
verses.text: —"I have already taken leave of the brethren who are in that city.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:68
verses.text: The decrees of the Church are of greater importance than a residence in Rome".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:69
verses.text: The Emperor.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:70
verses.text: —"You have three days to consider whether you will sign the document and return to Rome; if not, you must choose the place of your banishment".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:71
verses.text: Liberius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:72
verses.text: —"Neither three days nor three months can change my sentiments.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:73
verses.text: Send me wherever you please".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:74
verses.text: After the lapse of two days the emperor sent for Liberius, and finding his opinions unchanged, he commanded him to be banished to Beroea, a city of Thrace.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:75
verses.text: Upon the departure of Liberius, the emperor sent him five hundred pieces of gold to defray his expenses.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:76
verses.text: Liberius said to the messenger who brought them, "Go, and give them back to the emperor; he has need of them to pay his troops".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:77
verses.text: The empress also sent him a sum of the same amount; he said, "Take it to the emperor, for he may want it to pay his troops; but if not, let it be given to Auxentius and Epictetus, for they stand in need of it".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:78
verses.text: Eusebius the eunuch brought him other sums of money, and he thus addressed him: "You have turned all the churches of the world into a desert, and do you bring alms to me, as to a criminal? Begone, and become first a Christian".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 13:79
verses.text: He was sent into exile three days afterwards, without having accepted anything that was offered him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 14:1
verses.text: Chapter XIV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 14:2
verses.text: —Concerning the Banishment and Return of the Holy Liberius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 14:3
verses.text: This victorious champion of the truth was sent into Thrace, according to the imperial order.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 14:4
verses.text: Two years after this event Constantius went to Rome.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 14:5
verses.text: The ladies of rank urged their husbands to petition the emperor for the restoration of the shepherd to his flock: they added, that if this were not granted, they would desert them, and go themselves after their great pastor.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 14:6
verses.text: Their husbands replied, that they were afraid of incurring the resentment of the emperor.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 14:7
verses.text: "If we were to ask him," they continued, "being men, he would deem it an unpardonable offence; but if you were yourselves to present the petition, he would at any rate spare you, and would either accede to your request, or else dismiss you without injury".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 14:8
verses.text: These noble ladies adopted this suggestion, and presented themselves before the emperor in all their customary splendour of array, that so the sovereign, judging their rank from their dress, might count them worthy of being treated with courtesy and kindness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 14:9
verses.text: Thus entering the presence, they besought him to take pity on the condition of so large a city, deprived of its shepherd, and made an easy prey to the attacks of wolves.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 14:10
verses.text: The emperor replied, that the flock possessed a shepherd capable of tending it, and that no other was needed in the city.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 14:11
verses.text: For after the banishment of the great Liberius, one of his deacons, named Felix, had been appointed bishop.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 14:12
verses.text: He preserved inviolate the doctrines set forth in the Nicene confession of faith, yet he held communion with those who had corrupted that faith.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 14:13
verses.text: For this reason none of the citizens of Rome would enter the House of Prayer while he was in it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 14:14
verses.text: The ladies mentioned these facts to the emperor.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 14:15
verses.text: Their persuasions were successful; and he commanded that the great Liberius should be recalled from exile, and that the two bishops should conjointly rule the Church.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 14:16
verses.text: The edict of the emperor was read in the circus, and the multitude shouted that the imperial ordinance was just; that the spectators were divided into two factions, each deriving its name from its own colours, and that each faction would now have its own bishop.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 14:17
verses.text: After having thus ridiculed the edict of the emperor, they all exclaimed with one voice, "One God, one Christ, one bishop".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 14:18
verses.text: I have deemed it right to set down their precise words.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 14:19
verses.text: Some time after this Christian people had uttered these pious and righteous acclamations, the holy Liberius returned, and Felix retired to another city.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 14:20
verses.text: I have, for the sake of preserving order, appended this narrative to what relates to the proceedings of the bishops at Milan.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 14:21
verses.text: I shall now return to the relation of events in their due course.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:1
verses.text: Chapter XV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:2
verses.text: —Council of Ariminum.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:3
verses.text: When all who defended the faith had been removed, those who moulded the mind of the emperor according to their own will, flattering themselves that the faith which they opposed might be easily subverted, and Arianism established in its stead, persuaded Constantius to convene the Bishops of both East and West at Ariminum, in order to remove from the Creed the terms which had been devised by the Fathers to counteract the corrupt craft of Arius,—"substance," and "of one substance".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:4
verses.text: For they would have it that these terms had caused dissension between church and church.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:5
verses.text: On their assembling in synod the partizans of the Arian faction strove to trick the majority of the bishops, especially those of cities of the Western Empire, who were men of simple and unsophisticated ways.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:6
verses.text: The body of the Church, they argued again and again, must not be torn asunder for the sake of two terms which are not to be found in the Bible; and, while they confessed the propriety of describing the Son as in all things "like" the Father, pressed the omission of the word "substance" as unscriptural.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:7
verses.text: The motives, however, of the propounders of these views were seen through by the Council, and they were consequently repudiated.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:8
verses.text: The orthodox bishops declared their mind to the emperor in a letter; for, said they, we are sons and heirs of the Fathers of the Council of Nicaea, and if we were to have the hardihood to take away anything from what was by them subscribed, or to add anything to what they so excellently settled, we should declare ourselves no true sons, but accusers of them that begat us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:9
verses.text: But the exact terms of their confession of faith will be more accurately given in the words of their letter to Constantius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:10
verses.text: Letterwritten to the Emperor Constantius by the Synod assembled at Ariminum.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:11
verses.text: "Summoned, we believe, at the bidding of God, and in obedience to your piety, we bishops of the Western Church assembled in synod at Ariminum in order that the faith of the Church Catholic might be set forth, and its opponents exposed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:12
verses.text: After long consideration we have found it to be plainly best for us to hold fast and guard, and by guarding keep safe unto the end, the faith established from the first, preached by Prophets, and Evangelists, and Apostles, through our Lord Jesus Christ, warden of thy empire, and champion of thy salvation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:13
verses.text: For it is plainly absurd and unlawful to make any change in the doctrines rightly and justly defined, and in matters examined at Nicaea with the cognisance of the right glorious Constantine, thy Father and Emperor, whereof the teaching and spirit was published and preached that mankind might hear and understand.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:14
verses.text: This faith was destined to be the one rival and destroyer of the Arian heresy, and by it not only the Arian itself, but likewise all other heresies were undone.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:15
verses.text: To this faith to add aught is verily perilous; from it to subtract aught is to run great risk.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:16
verses.text: If it have either addition or loss, our foes will feel free to act as they please.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:17
verses.text: Accordingly Ursacius and Valens, declared adherents and friends of the Arian dogma, were pronounced separate from our communion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:18
verses.text: To keep their place in it, they asked to be granted a locus penitentiae and pardon for all the points wherein they had owned themselves in error; as is testified by the documents written by themselves, by means of which they obtained favour and forgiveness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:19
verses.text: These events were going on at the very time when the synod was meeting at Milan, the presbyters of the church of Rome being also present.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:20
verses.text: It was known that Constantine, who, though dead, is worthy of remembrance, had, with all exactitude and care, set forth the creed drawn up: and now that, after receiving Baptism, he was dead, and had passed away to the peace which he deserved.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:21
verses.text: We judged it absurd for us after him to indulge in any innovation, and throw a slur on all the holy confessors and martyrs who had devised and formulated this doctrine, in that their minds have ever remained bound by the old bond of the Church.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:22
verses.text: Their faith God has handed down even to the times of thy own reign, through our Lord Jesus Christ, by Whose grace such empire is thine that thou rulest over all the world.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:23
verses.text: Yet again those pitiable and wretched men, with lawless daring, have proclaimed themselves preachers of their unholy opinion, and are taking in hand the overthrow of all the force of the truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:24
verses.text: For when at thy command the synod assembled, then they laid bare their own disingenuous desires.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:25
verses.text: For they set about trying through villany and confusion to make innovation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:26
verses.text: They got hold of certain of their own following—one Germanius, and Auxentius, and Caius, promoters of heresy and discord, whose doctrine, though but one, transcends a very host of blasphemies.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:27
verses.text: When, however, they became aware that we were not of their way of thinking, nor in sympathy with their vicious projects, they made their way into our meeting as though to make some other proposal, but a very short time was enough to convict them of their real intentions.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:28
verses.text: Therefore in order to save the management of the Church from falling from time to time into the same difficulties, and to prevent them from being confounded in whirlpools of disturbance and disorder, it has seemed the safe course to keep what has been defined aforetime fixed and unchanged, and to separate the above-named from our communion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:29
verses.text: Wherefore we have sent envoys to your clemency to signify and explain the mind of the synod as expressed in this letter.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:30
verses.text: These envoys before all things we have charged to guard the truth in accordance with the old and right definitions.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:31
verses.text: They are to inform your holiness, not as did Ursacius and Valens, that there will be peace if the truth be upset; for how can the destroyers of peace be agents of peace? but rather that these changes will bring strife and disturbance, as well on the rest of the cities, as on the Roman church.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:32
verses.text: Wherefore we beseech your clemency to receive our envoys with kindly ears and gentle mien, and not to suffer any new thing to flout the dead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:33
verses.text: Suffer us to abide in the definition and settlement of our Fathers, whom we would unhesitatingly declare to have done all they did with intelligence and wisdom, and with the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:34
verses.text: The innovation now sought to be introduced is filling the faithful with unbelief, and unbelievers with credulity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:35
verses.text: "We beg you to order bishops in distant parts, who are afflicted alike by advanced age and poverty, to be provided with facilities for travelling home, that the churches be not left long deprived of their bishops.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:36
verses.text: "And yet again this one thing we supplicate, that nothing be taken from or added to the established doctrines, but that all remain unbroken, as they have been preserved by your father's piety, and to our own day.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:37
verses.text: Let us toil no longer nor be kept away from our own dioceses, but let the bishops with their own people spend their days in peace, in prayer, and in worship, offering supplication for thy empire, and health, and peace, which God shall grant thee for ever and ever.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:38
verses.text: Our envoys, who will also instruct your holiness out of the sacred Scriptures, convey the signatures and salutations of the bishops".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:39
verses.text: The letter was written, and the envoys sent, but the high officers of the Imperial Court, though they took the despatch and delivered it to their master, refused to introduce the envoys, on the ground that the sovereign was occupied with state affairs.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:40
verses.text: They took this course in the hope that the bishops, annoyed at delay, and eager to return to the cities entrusted to their care, would at length be compelled themselves to break up and disperse the bulwark erected against heresy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:41
verses.text: But their ingenuity was frustrated, for the noble champions of the Faith despatched a second letter to the emperor, exhorting him to admit the envoys to audience and dissolve the synod.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:42
verses.text: This letter I subjoin.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:43
verses.text: The Second Letter of the Synod to Constantius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:44
verses.text: "To Constantius the Victorious, the pious emperor, the bishops assembled at Ariminum send greeting.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:45
verses.text: "Most illustrious lord and autocrat, we have received the letter of your clemency, informing us that, in consequence of occupations of state, you have hitherto been unable to see our envoys.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:46
verses.text: You bid us await their return, that your piety may come to a decision on the object we have in view, and on the decrees of our predecessors.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:47
verses.text: But we venture in this letter to repeat to your clemency the point which we urged before, for we have in no way withdrawn from our position.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:48
verses.text: We entreat you to receive with benign countenance the letter of our humility, wherein now we make answer to your piety, and the points which we have ordered to be submitted to your benignity by our envoys.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:49
verses.text: Your clemency is no less aware than we are ourselves how serious and unfitting a state of things it is, that in the time of your most happy reign so many churches should seem to be without bishops.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 15:50
verses.text: Wherefore once again, most glorious autocrat, we beseech you that, if it be pleasing to your humanity, you will command us to return to our churches before the rigour of winter, that we may be able, with our people, as we have done and ever do, to offer most earnest prayers for the health and wealth of your empire to Almighty God, and to Christ His Son, our Lord and Saviour".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 16:1
verses.text: Chapter XVI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 16:2
verses.text: —Concerning the Synod held at Nica in Thrace, and the Confession of Faith drawn up there.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 16:3
verses.text: After this letter they irritated the emperor, and got the majority of the bishops, against their will, to a certain town of Thrace, of the name of Nica.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 16:4
verses.text: Some simple men they deluded, and others they terrified, into carrying out their old contrivance for injuring the true religion, by erasing the words "Substance" and "of one Substance" from the Creed, and inserting instead of them the word "like".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 16:5
verses.text: I insert their formula in this history, not as being couched in proper terms, but because it convicts the faction of Arius, for it is not even accepted by the disaffected of the present time.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 16:6
verses.text: Now, instead of "the like" they preach "the unlike".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 16:7
verses.text: Unsound Creed put forth at Nica in Thrace.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 16:8
verses.text: "We believe in one only true God, Father Almighty, of Whom are all things.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 16:9
verses.text: And in the only-begotten Son of God, Who before all ages and before every beginning was begotten of God, through Whom all things were made, both visible and invisible: alone begotten, only-begotten of the Father alone, God of God: like the Father that begat Him, according to the Scriptures, Whose generation no one knoweth except only the Father that begat Him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 16:10
verses.text: This Only-begotten Son of God, sent by His Father, we know to have come down from heaven, as it is written, for the destruction of sin and death; begotten of the Holy Ghost and the Virgin Mary, as it is written, according to the flesh.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 16:11
verses.text: Who companied with His disciples, and when the dispensation was fulfilled, according to the Father's will, was crucified, dead, and buried, and descended to the world below, at Whom Hell himself trembled.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 16:12
verses.text: On the third day He rose from the dead and companied with His disciples forty days.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 16:13
verses.text: He was taken up into Heaven, and sitteth on the right hand of His Father, and is coming at the last day of the Resurrection, in His Father's Glory, to render to every one according to his works.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 16:14
verses.text: And we believe in the Holy Ghost, which the Only-begotten Son of God, Jesus Christ, both God and Lord, promised to send to man, the Comforter, as it is written, the Spirit of Truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 16:15
verses.text: This Spirit He Himself sent after He had ascended into Heaven and sat at the right hand of the Father, from thence to come to judge both quick and dead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 16:16
verses.text: But the word 'the Substance,' which was too simply inserted by the Fathers, and, not being understood by the people, was a cause of scandal through its not being found in the Scriptures, it hath seemed good to us to remove, and that for the future no mention whatever be permitted of 'Substance,' on account of the sacred Scriptures nowhere making any mention of the 'Substance' of the Father and the Son.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 16:17
verses.text: Nor must one 'essence' be named in relation to the person of Father, Son, and Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 16:18
verses.text: And we call the Son like the Father, as the Holy Scriptures call Him and teach; but all the heresies, both those already condemned, and any, if such there be, which have risen against the document thus put forth, let them be Anathema".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 16:19
verses.text: This Creed was subscribed by the bishops, some being frightened and some cajoled, but those who refused to give in their adhesion were banished to the most remote regions of the world.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 17:1
verses.text: Chapter XVII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 17:2
verses.text: —Synodical Act of Damasus, Bishop of Rome, and of the Western Bishops, about the Council at Ariminum.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 17:3
verses.text: The condemnation of this formula by all the champions of the truth, and specially those of the West, is shewn by the letter which they wrote to the Illyrians.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 17:4
verses.text: First of the signatories was Damasus, who obtained the presidency of the church of Rome after Liberius, and was adorned with many virtues.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 17:5
verses.text: With him signed ninety bishops of Italy and Galatia, now called Gaul, who met together at Rome.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 17:6
verses.text: I would have inserted their names but that I thought it superfluous.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 17:7
verses.text: ————————————  "The bishops assembled at Rome in sacred synod, Damasus and Valerianus and the rest, to their beloved brethren the bishops of Illyria, send greeting in God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 17:8
verses.text: "We believe that we, priests of God, by whom it is right for the rest to be instructed, are holding and teaching our people the Holy Creed which was founded on the teaching of the Apostles, and in no way departs from the definitions of the Fathers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 17:9
verses.text: But through a report of the brethren in Gaul and Venetia we have learnt that certain men are fallen into heresy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 17:10
verses.text: "It is the duty of the bishops not only to take precautions against this mischief, but also to make a stand against whatever divergent teaching has arisen, either from incomplete instruction, or the simplicity of readers of unsound commentators.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 17:11
verses.text: They should be minded not to slide into slippery paths, but rather whensoever divergent counsels are carried to their ears, to hold fast the doctrine of our fathers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 17:12
verses.text: It has, therefore, been decided that Auxentius of Milan is in this matter specially condemned.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 17:13
verses.text: So it is right that all the teachers of the law in the Roman Empire should be well instructed in the law, and not befoul the faith with divergent doctrines.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 17:14
verses.text: "When first the wickedness of the heretics began to flourish, and when, as now, the blasphemy of the Arians was crawling to the front, our fathers, three hundred and eighteen bishops, the holiest prelates in the Roman Empire, deliberated at Nicaea.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 17:15
verses.text: The wall which they set up against the weapons of the devil, and the antidote wherewith they repelled his deadly poisons, was their confession that the Father and the Son are of one substance, one godhead, one virtue, one power, one likeness, and that the Holy Ghost is of the same essence and substance.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 17:16
verses.text: Whoever did not thus think was judged separate from our communion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 17:17
verses.text: Their deliberation was worthy of all respect, and their definition sound.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 17:18
verses.text: But certain men have intended by other later discussions to corrupt and befoul it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 17:19
verses.text: Yet, at the very outset, error was so far set right by the bishops on whom the attempt was made at Ariminum to compel them to manipulate or innovate on the faith, that they confessed themselves seduced by opposite arguments, or owned that they had not perceived any contradiction to the opinion of the Fathers delivered at Nicaea.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 17:20
verses.text: No prejudice could arise from the number of bishops gathered at Ariminum, since it is well known that neither the bishop of the Romans, whose opinion ought before all others to have been waited for, nor Vincentius, whose stainless episcopate had lasted so many years, nor the rest, gave in their adhesion to such doctrines.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 17:21
verses.text: And this is the more significant, since, as has been already said, the very men who seemed to be tricked into surrender, themselves, in their wiser moments, testified their disapproval.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 17:22
verses.text: "Your sincerity then perceives that this one faith, which was founded at Nicaea on the authority of the Apostles, ought to be kept secure for ever.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 17:23
verses.text: You perceive that with us, the bishops of the East, who confess themselves Catholic, and the western bishops, together glory in it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 17:24
verses.text: We believe that before long those who think otherwise ought without delay to be put out from our communion, and deprived of the name of bishop, that their flocks may be freed from error and breathe freely.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 17:25
verses.text: For they cannot be expected to correct the errors of their people when they themselves are the victims of error.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 17:26
verses.text: May the opinion of your reverence be in harmony with that of all the priests of God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 17:27
verses.text: We believe you to be fixed and firm in it, and thus ought we rightly to believe with you.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 17:28
verses.text: May your charity make us glad by your reply.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 17:29
verses.text: "Beloved brethren, farewell".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 18:1
verses.text: Chapter XVIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 18:2
verses.text: —The Letter of Athanasius, Bishop of Alexandria, concerning the same Council.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 18:3
verses.text: The great Athanasius also, in his letter to the Africans, writes thus about the council at Ariminum.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 18:4
verses.text: "Under these circumstances who will tolerate any mention of the council of Ariminum or any other beside the Nicene? Who would not express detestation of the setting aside of the words of the Fathers, and the preference for those introduced at Ariminum by violence and party strife? Who would wish to be associated with these men—fellows who do not, forsooth, accept their own words? In their own ten or a dozen synods they have laid down, as has been narrated already, now one thing now another; and at the present time these synods, one after another, they are themselves openly denouncing.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 18:5
verses.text: They are now suffering the fate undergone of old by the traitors of the Jews.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 18:6
verses.text: For as is written in the Book of the Prophet Jeremiah "they have forsaken me the fountain of living waters and hewed them out cisterns, broken cisterns that can hold no water," so these men, in their opposition to the oecumenical synod, have hewed for themselves many synods which have all proved vain and like "buds that yield no meal," let us not therefore admit those who cite the council of Ariminum or any other but that of Nicaea, for indeed the very citers of Ariminum do not seem to know what was done there; if they had they would have held their tongues.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 18:7
verses.text: For you, beloved, have learnt from your own representatives at that Council, and are consequently very well aware, that Ursacius, Valens, Eudoxius, and Auxentius, and with them Demophilus were asked to anathematize the Arian heresy, and made excuse, choosing rather to be its champions, and so were all deposed for making propositions contrary to the Nicene decrees.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 18:8
verses.text: The bishops, on the contrary, who were the true servants of the Lord, and of the right faith,—about two hundred in number,—declared their adherence to the Nicene Council alone, and their refusal to entertain the thought of either subtraction from, or addition to, its decrees.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 18:9
verses.text: This conclusion they have communicated to Constantius, by whose order the council assembled.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 18:10
verses.text: On the other hand the bishops who were deposed at Ariminum have been received by Constantius, and have succeeded in getting the two hundred who sentenced them grossly insulted, and threatened with not being allowed to return to their dioceses, and with having to undergo rigorous treatment in Thrace, and that in the winter, in order to force them to accept the innovators' measures.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 18:11
verses.text: If, then, we hear any one appealing to Ariminum, show us, let us rejoin, first the sentence of deposition, and then the document drawn up by the bishops, in which they declare that they do not seek to go beyond the terms drawn up by the Nicene Fathers, nor appeal to any other council than that of Nicaea.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 18:12
verses.text: In reality, these are just the facts they conceal, while they put prominently forward the forced confession of Thrace.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 18:13
verses.text: They do but shew themselves friends of the Arian heresy, and strangers to the sound faith.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 18:14
verses.text: Only let any one be willing to put side by side that great synod, and those others to which these men appeal, and he will perceive, on the one side, true religion, on the other, folly and disorder.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 18:15
verses.text: The fathers of Nicaea met together not after being deposed, but after confessing that the Son was of the Substance of the Father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 18:16
verses.text: These men were deposed once, a second time, and again a third time at Ariminum, and then dared to lay down that it is wrong to attribute Substance or Essence to God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 18:17
verses.text: So strange and so many were the tricks and machinations concocted by the mad gang of Arius in the West against the dogmas of the Truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 19:1
verses.text: Chapter XIX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 19:2
verses.text: —Concerning the cunning of Leontius, Bishop of Antioch, and the boldness of Flavianus and Diodorus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 19:3
verses.text: At Antioch Placidus was succeeded by Stephanus, who was expelled from the Church.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 19:4
verses.text: Leontius then accepted the Primacy, but in violation of the decrees of the Nicene Council, for he had mutilated himself, and was an eunuch.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 19:5
verses.text: The cause of his rash deed is thus narrated by the blessed Athanasius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 19:6
verses.text: Leontius, it seems, was the victim of slanderous statements on account of a certain young woman of the name of Eustolia.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 19:7
verses.text: Finding himself prevented from dwelling with her he mutilated himself for her sake, in order that he might feel free to live with her.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 19:8
verses.text: But he did not clear himself of suspicion, and all the more for this reason was deposed from the presbyterate.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 19:9
verses.text: So much Athanasius has written about the rest of his earlier life.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 19:10
verses.text: I shall now give a summary exposure of his evil conduct.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 19:11
verses.text: Now though he shared the Arian error, he always endeavoured to conceal his unsoundness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 19:12
verses.text: He observed that the clergy and the rest of the people were divided into two parts, the one, in giving glory to the Son, using the conjunction "and," the other using the preposition "through" of the Son, and applying "in" to the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 19:13
verses.text: He himself offered all the doxology in silence, and all that those standing near him could hear was the "For ever and ever".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 19:14
verses.text: And had not the exceeding wickedness of his soul been betrayed by other means, it might have been said that he adopted this contrivance from a wish to promote concord among the people.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 19:15
verses.text: But when he had wrought much mischief to the champions of the truth, and continued to give every support to the promoters of impiety, he was convicted of concealing his own unsoundness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 19:16
verses.text: He was influenced both by his fear of the people, and by the grievous threats which Constantius had uttered against any who had dared to say that the Son was unlike the Father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 19:17
verses.text: His real sentiments were however proved by his conduct.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 19:18
verses.text: Followers of the Apostolic doctrines never received from him either ordination or indeed the least encouragement.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 19:19
verses.text: Men, on the other hand, who sided with the Arian superstition, were both allowed perfect liberty in expressing their opinions, and were from time to time admitted to priestly office.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 19:20
verses.text: At this juncture Aetius, the master of Eunomius, who promoted the Arian error by his speculations, was admitted to the diaconate.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 19:21
verses.text: Flavianus and Diodorus, however, who had embraced an ascetic career, and were open champions of the Apostolic decrees, publicly protested against the attacks of Leontius against true religion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 19:22
verses.text: That a man nurtured in iniquity and scheming to win notoriety by ungodliness should be counted worthy of the diaconate, was, they urged, a disgrace to the Church.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 19:23
verses.text: They further threatened that they would withdraw from his communion, travel to the western empire, and publish his plots to the world.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 19:24
verses.text: Leontius was now alarmed, and suspended Aetius from his sacred office, but continued to show him marked favour.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 19:25
verses.text: That excellent pair Flavianus and Diodorus, though not yet admitted to the priesthood and still ranked with the laity, worked night and day to stimulate men's zeal for truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 19:26
verses.text: They were the first to divide choirs into two parts, and to teach them to sing the psalms of David antiphonally.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 19:27
verses.text: Introduced first at Antioch, the practice spread in all directions, and penetrated to the ends of the earth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 19:28
verses.text: Its originators now collected the lovers of the Divine word and work into the Churches of the Martyrs, and with them spent the night in singing psalms to God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 19:29
verses.text: When Leontius perceived this, he did not think it safe to try to prevent them, for he saw that the people were exceedingly well-disposed towards these excellent men.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 19:30
verses.text: However, putting a colour of courtesy on his speech, he requested that they would perform this act of worship in the churches.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 19:31
verses.text: They were perfectly well aware of his evil intent.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 19:32
verses.text: Nevertheless they set about obeying his behest and readily summoned their choir to the Church, exhorting them to sing praises to the good Lord.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 19:33
verses.text: Nothing, however, could induce Leontius to correct his wickedness, but he put on the mask of equity, and concealed the iniquity of Stephanus and Placidus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 19:34
verses.text: Men who had accepted the corruption of the faith of priests and deacons, although they had embraced a life of vile irregularity, he added to the roll; while others adorned with every kind of virtue and firm adherents of apostolic doctrines, he left unrecognised.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 19:35
verses.text: Thus it came to pass that among the clergy were numbered a majority of men tainted with heresy, while the mass of the laity were champions of the Faith, and even professional teachers lacked courage to lay bare their blasphemy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 19:36
verses.text: In truth the deeds of impiety and iniquity done by Placidus, Stephanus, and Leontius, in Antioch are so many as to want a special history of their own, and so terrible as to be worthy of the lament of David; for of them too it must be said "For lo thy enemies make a murmuring and they that hate thee lift up their head.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 19:37
verses.text: They have imagined craftily against the people and taken counsel against thy secret ones.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 19:38
verses.text: They have said come and let us root them out that they be no more a people: and that the name of Israel may be no more in remembrance".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 19:39
verses.text: Let us now continue the course of our narrative.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 20:1
verses.text: Chapter XX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 20:2
verses.text: —Concerning the innovations of Eudoxius, of Germanicia, and the zeal of Basilius of Ancyra, and of Eustathius of Sebasteia against him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 20:3
verses.text: Germanicia is a city on the coasts of Cilicia, Syria, and Cappadocia, and belongs to the province called Euphratisia.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 20:4
verses.text: Eudoxius, the head of its church, directly he heard of the death of Leontius, betook himself to Antioch and clutched the see, where he ravaged the vineyard of the Lord like a wild boar.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 20:5
verses.text: He did not even attempt to hide his evil ways, like Leontius, but raged in direct attack upon the apostolic decrees, and involved in various troubles all who had the hardihood to gainsay him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 20:6
verses.text: Now at this time Basilius had succeeded Marcellus, and held the helm of the church of Ancyra, the capital of Galatia, and Sebastia, the chief city of Armenia, was under the guidance of Eustathius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 20:7
verses.text: No sooner had these bishops heard of the iniquity and madness of Eudoxius, than they wrote to inform the Emperor Constantius of his audacity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 20:8
verses.text: Constantius was now still tarrying in the west, and, after the death of the tyrants, was endeavouring to heal the harm they had caused.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 20:9
verses.text: Both bishops were well known to the Emperor and had great influence with him on account of the high character they bore.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 21:1
verses.text: Chapter XXI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 21:2
verses.text: —Of the Second Council of Nicaea.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 21:3
verses.text: On receipt of these despatches Constantius wrote to the Antiochenes denying that he had committed the see of Antioch to Eudoxius, as Eudoxius had publicly announced.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 21:4
verses.text: He ordered that Eudoxius be banished, and be punished for the course he had taken at the Bithynian Nicaea, where he had ordered the synod to assemble.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 21:5
verses.text: Eudoxius himself had persuaded the officers entrusted with authority in the imperial household to fix Nicaea for the Council.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 21:6
verses.text: But the Supreme Ruler and Governor, who knows the future like the past, stopped the assembly by a mighty earthquake, whereby the greater part of the city was overthrown, and most of the inhabitants destroyed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 21:7
verses.text: On learning this the assembled bishops were seized with panic, and returned to their own churches.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 21:8
verses.text: But I regard this as a contrivance of the divine wisdom, for in that city the doctrine of the faith of the apostles had been defined by the holy Fathers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 21:9
verses.text: In that same city the bishops who were assembling on this later occasion were intending to lay down the contrary.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 21:10
verses.text: The sameness of name would have been sure to furnish a means of deception to the Arian crew, and trick unsophisticated souls.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 21:11
verses.text: They meant to call the council "the Nicene," and identify it with the famous council of old.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 21:12
verses.text: But He who has care for the churches disbanded the synod.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 22:1
verses.text: Chapter XXII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 22:2
verses.text: —Of the Council held at Seleucia in Isauria.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 22:3
verses.text: After a time, at the suggestion of the accusers of Eudoxius, Constantius ordered the synod to be held at Seleucia.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 22:4
verses.text: This town of Isauria lies on the seashore and is the chief town of the district.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 22:5
verses.text: Hither the bishops of the East, and with them those of Pontus in Asia, were ordered to assemble.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 22:6
verses.text: The see of Caesarea, the capital of Palestine, was now held by Acacius, who had succeeded Eusebius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 22:7
verses.text: He had been condemned by the council of Sardica, but had expressed contempt for so large an assembly of bishops, and had refused to accept their adverse decision.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 22:8
verses.text: At Jerusalem Macarius, whom I have often mentioned, was succeeded by Maximus, a man conspicuous in his struggles on behalf of religion, for he had been deprived of his right eye and maimed in his right arm.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 22:9
verses.text: On his translation to the life which knows no old age, Cyrillus, an earnest champion of the apostolic decrees, was dignified with the Episcopal office.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 22:10
verses.text: These men in their contentions with one another for the first place brought great calamities on the state.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 22:11
verses.text: Acacius seized some small occasion, deposed Cyrillus, and drove him from Jerusalem.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 22:12
verses.text: But Cyrillus passed by Antioch, which he had found without a pastor, and came to Tarsus, where he dwelt with the excellent Silvanus, then bishop of that see.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 22:13
verses.text: No sooner did Acacius become aware of this than he wrote to Silvanus and informed him of the deposition of Cyrillus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 22:14
verses.text: Silvanus however, both out of regard for Cyrillus, and not without suspicion of his people, who greatly enjoyed the stranger's teaching, refused to prohibit him from taking a part in the ministrations of the church.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 22:15
verses.text: When however they had arrived at Seleucia, Cyrillus joined with the party of Basilius and Eustathius and Silvanus and the rest in the council.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 22:16
verses.text: But when Acacius joined the assembled bishops, who numbered one hundred and fifty, he refused to be associated in their counsels before Cyrillus, as one stripped of his bishopric, had been put out from among them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 22:17
verses.text: There were some who, eager for peace, besought Cyrillus to withdraw, with a pledge that after the decision of the decrees they would enquire into his case.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 22:18
verses.text: He would not give way, and Acacius left them and went out.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 22:19
verses.text: Then meeting Eudoxius he removed his alarm, and encouraged him with a promise that he would stand his friend and supporter.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 22:20
verses.text: Thus he hindered him from taking part in the council, and set out with him for Constantinople.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:2
verses.text: —Of what befell the orthodox bishops at Constantinople.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:3
verses.text: Constantius, on his return from the West, passed some time at Constantinople.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:4
verses.text: There Acacius urged many accusations against the assembled bishops in presence of the emperor, called them a set of vile characters convoked for the ruin and destruction of the churches, and so fired the imperial wrath.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:5
verses.text: And not least was Constantius moved by what was alleged against Cyrillus, "for," said Acachius, "the holy robe, which the illustrious Constantine the emperor, in his desire to honour the church of Jerusalem, gave to Macarius, the bishop of that city, to be worn when he performed the rite of divine baptism, all fashioned with golden threads as it was, has been sold by Cyrillus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:6
verses.text: It has been bought," he continued, "by a certain stage dancer; dancing about when he was wearing it, he fell down and perished.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:7
verses.text: With a man like this Cyrillus," he went on, "they set themselves up to judge and decide for the rest of the world".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:8
verses.text: The influential party at the court made this an occasion for persuading the emperor not to summon the whole synod, for they were alarmed at the concord of the majority, but only ten leading men.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:9
verses.text: Of these were Eustathius of Armenia, Basilius of Galatia, Silvanus of Tarsus, and Eleusius of Cyzicus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:10
verses.text: On their arrival they urged the emperor that Eudoxius should be convicted of blasphemy and lawlessness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:11
verses.text: Constantius, however, schooled by the opposite party, replied that a decision must first be come to on matters concerning the faith, and that afterwards the case of Eudoxius should be enquired into.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:12
verses.text: Basilius, relying on his former intimacy, ventured boldly to object to the emperor that he was attacking the apostolic decrees; but Constantius took this ill, and told Basilius to hold his tongue, "for to you," said he, "the disturbance of the churches is due".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:13
verses.text: When Basilius was silenced, Eustathius intervened and said, "since, sir, you wish a decision to be come to on what concerns the faith, consider the blasphemies rashly uttered against the Only Begotten by Eudoxius," and as he spoke he produced the exposition of faith wherein, besides many other impieties, were found the following expressions: "Things that are spoken of in unlike terms are unlike in substance:" "There is one God the Father of whom are all things, and one Lord Jesus Christ through whom are all things".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:14
verses.text: Now the term "of whom" is unlike the term "through whom;" so the Son is unlike God the Father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:15
verses.text: Constantius ordered this exposition of the faith to be read, and was displeased with the blasphemy which it involved.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:16
verses.text: He therefore asked Eudoxius if he had drawn it up.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:17
verses.text: Eudoxius instantly repudiated the authorship, and said that it was written by Aetius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:18
verses.text: Now Aetius was he whom Leontius, in dread of the accusations of Flavianus and Diodorus, had formerly degraded from the diaconate.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:19
verses.text: He had also been the supporter of Georgius, the treacherous foe of the Alexandrians, alike in his impious words and his unholy deeds.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:20
verses.text: At the present time he was associated with Eunomius and Eudoxius; for, on the death of Leontius, when Eudoxius had laid violent hands on the episcopal throne of the church at Antioch, he returned from Egypt with Eunomius, and, as he found Eudoxius to be of the same way of thinking as himself, a sybarite in luxury as well as a heretic in faith, he chose Antioch as the most congenial place of abode, and both he and Eunomius were fast fixtures at the couches of Eudoxius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:21
verses.text: His highest ambition was to be a successful parasite, and he spent his whole time in going to gorge himself at one man's table or another's.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:22
verses.text: The emperor had been told all this, and now ordered Aetius to be brought before him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:23
verses.text: On his appearance Constantius showed him the document in question and proceeded to enquire if he was the author of its language.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:24
verses.text: Aetius, totally ignorant of what had taken place, and unaware of the drift of the enquiry, expected that he should win praise by confession, and owned that he was the author of the phrases in question.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:25
verses.text: Then the emperor perceived the greatness of his iniquity, and forthwith condemned him to exile and to be deported to a place in Phrygia.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:26
verses.text: So Aetius reaped disgrace as the fruit of blasphemy, and was cast out of the palace.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:27
verses.text: Eustathius then alleged that Eudoxius too held the same views, for that Aetius had shared his roof and his table, and had drawn up this blasphemous formula in submission to his judgement.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:28
verses.text: In proof of his contention that Eudoxius was concerned in drawing up the document he urged the fact that no one had attributed it to Aetius except Eudoxius himself.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:29
verses.text: To this the emperor enjoined that judges must not decide on conjecture, but are bound to make exact examination of the facts.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:30
verses.text: Eustathius assented, and urged that Eudoxius should give proof of his dissent from the sentiments attributed to him by anathematizing the composition of Aetius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:31
verses.text: This suggestion the emperor very readily accepted, and gave his orders accordingly; but Eudoxius drew back, and employed many shifts to evade compliance.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:32
verses.text: But when the emperor waxed wroth and threatened to send him off to share the exile of Aetius, on the ground that he was a partner in the blasphemy so punished, he repudiated his own doctrine, though both then and afterwards he persistently maintained it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:33
verses.text: However, he in his turn protested against the Eustathians that it was their duty to condemn the word "Homoüsion" as unscriptural.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:34
verses.text: Silvanus on the contrary pointed out that it was their duty to reject and expel from their holy assemblies the phrases "out of the non-existent" and "creature" and "of another substance," these terms being also unscriptural and found in the writings of neither prophets nor apostles.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:35
verses.text: Constantius decided that this was right, and bade the Arians pronounce the condemnation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:36
verses.text: At first they persisted in refusing; but in the end, when they saw the emperor's wrath, they consented, though much against the grain, to condemn the terms Silvanus had put before them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:37
verses.text: But all the more earnestly they insisted on their demand for the condemnation of the "Homoüsion".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:38
verses.text: But then with unanswerable logic Silvanus put both before the Arians and the emperor the truth that if God the Word is not of the non-Existent, He is not a Creature, and is not of another Substance.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:39
verses.text: He is then of one Substance with God Who begat Him, as God of God and Light of Light, and has the same nature as the Begetter.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:40
verses.text: This contention he urged with power and with truth, but not one of his hearers was convinced.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:41
verses.text: The party of Acacius and Eudoxius raised a mighty uproar; the emperor was angered, and threatened expulsion from their churches.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:42
verses.text: Thereupon Eleusius and Silvanus and the rest said that while authority to punish lay with the emperor, it was their province to decide on points of piety or impiety, and "we will not," they protested, "betray the doctrine of the Fathers".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:43
verses.text: Constantius ought to have admired both their wisdom and their courage, and their bold defence of the apostolic decrees, but he exiled them from their churches, and ordered others to be appointed in their place.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 23:44
verses.text: Thereupon Eudoxius laid violent hands on the Church of Constantinople; and on the expulsion of Eleusius from Cyzicus, Eunomius was appointed in his place.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 24:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 24:2
verses.text: —Synodical Epistle written against Aetius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 24:3
verses.text: After these transactions the emperor ordered Aetius to be condemned by a formal Letter, and, in obedience to the command, his companions in iniquity condemned their own associate.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 24:4
verses.text: Accordingly they wrote to Georgius, bishop of Alexandria, the letter about him to which I shall give a place in my history, in order to expose their wickedness, for they treated their friends and their foes precisely in the same way.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 24:5
verses.text: Copy of the Letter written by the whole council to Georgius against Aetius his deacon, on account of his iniquitous blasphemy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 24:6
verses.text: To the right honourable Lord Georgius, Bishop of Alexandria, the holy Synod in Constantinople assembled, Greeting.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 24:7
verses.text: In consequence of the condemnation of Aetius by the Synod, on account of his unlawful and most offensive writings, he has been dealt with by the bishops in accordance with the canons of the church.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 24:8
verses.text: He has been degraded from the diaconate and expelled from the Church, and our admonitions have gone forth that none are to read his unlawful epistles, but that on account of their unprofitable and worthless character they are to be cast aside.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 24:9
verses.text: We have further appended an anathema on him, if he abides in his opinion, and on his supporters.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 24:10
verses.text: It would naturally have followed that all the bishops met together in the Synod should have felt detestation of, and approved the sentence delivered against, a man who is the author of offences, disturbances and schisms, of agitation over all the world, and of rising of church against church.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 24:11
verses.text: But in spite of our prayers, and against all our expectation, Seras, Stephanus, Heliodorus and Theophilus and their party have not voted with us, and have not even consented to subscribe the sentence delivered against him, although Seras charged the aforenamed Aetius with another instance of insane arrogance, alleging that he, with still bolder impudence, had sprung forward to declare that what God had concealed from the Apostles had been now revealed to him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 24:12
verses.text: Even after these wild and boastful words, reported by Seras about Aetius, the aforenamed bishops were not put out of countenance, nor could they be induced to vote with us on his condemnation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 24:13
verses.text: We however with much long suffering bore with them for a great length of time, now indignant, now beseeching, now importuning them to join with us and make the decision of the Synod unanimous; and we persevered long in the hope that they might hear and agree and give in.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 24:14
verses.text: But when in spite of all this patience we could not shame them into acceptance of our declarations against the aforesaid offender, we counted the rule of the church more precious than the friendship of men, and pronounced against them a decree of excommunication, allowing them a period of six mouths for conversion, repentance, and the expression of a desire for union and harmony with the synod.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 24:15
verses.text: If within the given time they should turn and accept agreement with their brethren and assent to the decrees about Aetius, we decided that they should be received into the church, to the recovery of their own authority in synods, and our affection.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 24:16
verses.text: If however they obstinately persisted, and preferred human friendship to the canons of the church and our affection, then we judged them deposed from the rank of the bishops.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 24:17
verses.text: If they suffer degradation it is necessary to appoint other bishops in their place, that the lawful church may be duly ordered and at unity with herself, while all the bishops of every nation by uttering the same doctrine with one mind and one counsel preserve the bond of love.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 24:18
verses.text: To acquaint you with the decree of the Synod we have sent these present to your reverence, and pray that you may abide by them, and by the grace of Christ rule the churches under you aright and in peace.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 25:1
verses.text: Chapter XXV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 25:2
verses.text: —Of the causes which separated the Eunomians from the Arians.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 25:3
verses.text: Eunomius in his writings praises Aetius, styles him a man of God, and honours him with many compliments.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 25:4
verses.text: Yet he was at that time closely associated with the party by whom Aetius had been repudiated, and to them he owed his election to his bishopric.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 25:5
verses.text: Now the followers of Eudoxius and Acacius, who had assented to the decrees put forth at Nice in Thrace, already mentioned in this history, appointed other bishops in the churches of the adherents of Basilius and Eleusius in their stead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 25:6
verses.text: On other points I think it superfluous to write in detail.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 25:7
verses.text: I purpose only to relate what concerns Eunomius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 25:8
verses.text: For when Eunomius had seized on the see of Cyzicus in the lifetime of Eleusius, Eudoxius urged him to hide his opinions and not make them known to the party who were seeking a pretext to persecute him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 25:9
verses.text: Eudoxius was moved to offer this advice both by his knowledge that the diocese was sound in the faith and his experience of the anger manifested by Constantius against the party who asserted the only begotten Son of God to be a created being.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 25:10
verses.text: "Let us" said he to Eunomius "bide our time; when it comes we will preach what now we are keeping dark; educate the ignorant; and win over or compel or punish our opponents".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 25:11
verses.text: Eunomius, yielding to these suggestions, propounded his impious doctrine under the shadow of obscurity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 25:12
verses.text: Those of his hearers who had been nurtured on the divine oracles saw clearly that his utterances concealed under their surface a foul fester of error.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 25:13
verses.text: But however distressed they were they considered it less the part of prudence than of rashness to make any open protest, so they assumed a mask of heretical heterodoxy, and paid a visit to the bishop at his private residence with the earnest request that he would have regard to the distress of men borne hither and thither by different doctrines, and would plainly expound the truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 25:14
verses.text: Eunomius thus emboldened declared the sentiments which he secretly held.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 25:15
verses.text: The deputation then went on to remark that it was unfair and indeed quite wrong for the whole of his diocese to be prevented from having their share of the truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 25:16
verses.text: By these and similar arguments he was induced to lay bare his blasphemy in the public assemblies of the church.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 25:17
verses.text: Then his opponents hurried with angry fervour to Constantinople; first they indicted him before Eudoxius, and when Eudoxius refused to see them, sought an audience of the emperor and made lamentation over the ruin their bishop was wreaking among them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 25:18
