verses.text: "The sermons of Eunomius," they said, "are more impious than the blasphemies of Arius".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 25:19
verses.text: The wrath of Constantius was roused, and he commanded Eudoxius to send for Eunomius, and, on his conviction, to strip him of his bishopric.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 25:20
verses.text: Eudoxius, of course, though again and again importuned by the accusers, continued to delay taking action.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 25:21
verses.text: Then once more they approached the emperor with vociferous complaints that Eudoxius had not obeyed the imperial commands in any single particular, and was perfectly indifferent to the delivery of an important city to the blasphemies of Eunomius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 25:22
verses.text: Then said Constantius to Eudoxius, if you do not fetch Eunomius and try him, and on conviction of the charges brought against him, punish him, I shall exile you.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 25:23
verses.text: This threat frightened Eudoxius, so he wrote to Eunomius to escape from Cyzicus, and told him he had only himself to blame because he had not followed the hints given him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 25:24
verses.text: Eunomius accordingly withdrew in alarm, but he could not endure the disgrace, and endeavoured to fix the guilt of his betrayal on Eudoxius, maintaining that both he and Aetius had been cruelly treated.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 25:25
verses.text: And from that time he set up a sect of his own for all the men who were of his way of thinking and condemned his betrayal, separated from Eudoxius and joined with Eunomius, whose name they bear up to this day.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 25:26
verses.text: So Eunomius became the founder of a heresy, and added to the blasphemy of Arius by his own peculiar guilt.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 25:27
verses.text: He set up a sect of his own because he was a slave to his ambition, as the facts distinctly prove.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 25:28
verses.text: For when Aetius was condemned and exiled, Eunomius refused to accompany him, though he called him his master and a man of God, but remained closely associated with Eudoxius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 25:29
verses.text: But when his turn came he paid the penalty of his iniquity; he did not submit to the vote of the synod, but began to ordain bishops and presbyters, though himself deprived of his episcopal rank.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 25:30
verses.text: These then were the deeds done at Constantinople.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 26:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 26:2
verses.text: —Of the siege of the city of Nisibis,and the apostolic conversation of Bishop Jacobus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 26:3
verses.text: On war being waged against the Romans by Sapor King of Persia, Constantius mustered his forces and marched to Antioch.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 26:4
verses.text: But the enemy were driven forth, not by the Roman army, but by Him whom the pious in the Roman host worshipped as their God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 26:5
verses.text: How the victory was won I shall now proceed to relate.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 26:6
verses.text: Nisibis, sometimes called Antiochia Mygdonia, lies on the confines of the realms of Persia and of Rome.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 26:7
verses.text: In Nisibis Jacobus whom I named just now was at once bishop, guardian, and commander in chief.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 26:8
verses.text: He was a man who shone with the grace of a truly apostolic character.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 26:9
verses.text: His extraordinary and memorable miracles, which I have fully related in my religious history, I think it superfluous and irrelevant to enumerate again.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 26:10
verses.text: One however I will record because of the subject before us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 26:11
verses.text: The city which Jacobus ruled was now in possession of the Romans, and besieged by the Persian Army.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 26:12
verses.text: The blockade was prolonged for seventy days.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 26:13
verses.text: "Helepoles" and many other engines were advanced to the walls.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 26:14
verses.text: The town was begirt with a palisade and entrenchment, but still held out.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 26:15
verses.text: The river Mygdonius flowing through the middle of the town, at last the Persians dammed its stream a considerable distance up, and increased the height of its bank on both sides so as to shut the waters in.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 26:16
verses.text: When they saw that a great mass of water was collected and already beginning to overflow the dam, they suddenly launched it like an engine against the wall.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 26:17
verses.text: The impact was tremendous; the bulwarks could not sustain it, but gave way and fell down.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 26:18
verses.text: Just the same fate befell the other side of the circuit, through which the Mygdonius made its exit; it could not withstand the shock, and was carried away.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 26:19
verses.text: No sooner did Sapor see this than he expected to capture the rest of the city, and for all that day he rested for the mud to dry and the river to become passable.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 26:20
verses.text: Next day he attacked in full force, and looked to enter the city through the breaches that had been made.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 26:21
verses.text: But he found the wall built up on both sides, and all his labour vain.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 26:22
verses.text: For that holy man, through prayer, filled with valour both the troops and the rest of the townsfolk, and both built the walls, withstood the engines, and beat off the advancing foe.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 26:23
verses.text: And all this he did without approaching the walls, but by beseeching the Lord of all within the church.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 26:24
verses.text: Sapor, moreover, was not only astounded at the speed of the building of the walls but awed by another spectacle.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 26:25
verses.text: For he saw standing on the battlements one of kingly mien and all ablaze with purple robe and crown.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 26:26
verses.text: He supposed that this was the Roman emperor, and threatened his attendants with death for not having announced the imperial presence; but on their stoutly maintaining that their report had been a true one and that Constantius was at Antioch, he perceived the meaning of the vision and exclaimed "their God is fighting for the Romans".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 26:27
verses.text: Then the wretched man in a rage flung a javelin into the air, though he knew that he could not hit a bodiless being, but unable to curb his passion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 26:28
verses.text: Therefore the excellent Ephraim (he is the best writer among the Syrians) besought the divine Jacobus to mount the wall to see the barbarians and to let fly at them the darts of his curse.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 26:29
verses.text: So the divine man consented and climbed up into a tower but when he saw the innumerable host he discharged no other curse than to that mosquitoes and gnats might be sent forth upon them, so that by means of these tiny animals they might learn the might of the Protector of the Romans.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 26:30
verses.text: On his prayer followed clouds of mosquitoes and gnats; they filled the hollow trunks of the elephants, and the ears and nostrils of horses and other animals.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 26:31
verses.text: Finding the attack of these little creatures past endurance they broke their bridles, unseated their riders and threw the ranks into confusion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 26:32
verses.text: The Persians abandoned their camp and fled head-long.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 26:33
verses.text: So the wretched prince learned by a slight and kindly chastisement the power of the God who protects the pious, and marched his army home again, reaping for all the harvest of the siege not triumph but disgrace.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 27:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 27:2
verses.text: —Of the Council of Antioch and what was done there against the holy Meletius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 27:3
verses.text: At this time, Constantius was residing at Antioch.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 27:4
verses.text: The Persian war was over; there had been a time of peace, and he once again gathered bishops together with the object of making them all deny both the formula "of one substance" and also the formula "of different substance".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 27:5
verses.text: On the death of Leontius, Eudoxius had seized the see of Antioch, but on his expulsion and illegal establishment, after many synods, at Constantinople, the church of Antioch had been left without a shepherd.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 27:6
verses.text: Accordingly the assembled bishops, gathered in considerable numbers from every quarter, asserted that their primary obligation was to provide a pastor for the flock and that then with him they would deliberate on matters of faith.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 27:7
verses.text: It fell out opportunely that the divine Meletius who was ruling a certain city of Armenia had been grieved with the insubordination of the people under his rule and was now living without occupation elsewhere.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 27:8
verses.text: The Arian faction imagined that Meletius was of the same way of thinking as themselves, and an upholder of their doctrines.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 27:9
verses.text: They therefore petitioned Constantius to commit to his hands the reins of the Antiochene church.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 27:10
verses.text: Indeed in the hope of establishing their impiety there was no law that they did not fearlessly transgress; illegality was becoming the very foundation of their blasphemy; nor was this an isolated specimen of their irregular proceedings.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 27:11
verses.text: On the other hand the maintainers of apostolic doctrine, who were perfectly well aware of the soundness of the great Meletius, and had clear knowledge of his stainless character and wealth of virtue, came to a common vote, and took measures to have their resolution written out and subscribed by all without delay.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 27:12
verses.text: This document both parties as a bond of compromise entrusted to the safe keeping of a bishop who was a noble champion of the truth, Eusebius of Samosata.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 27:13
verses.text: And when the great Meletius had received the imperial summons and arrived, forth to meet him came all the higher ranks of the priesthood, forth came all the other orders of the church, and the whole population of the city.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 27:14
verses.text: There, too, were Jews and Gentiles all eager to see the great Meletius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 27:15
verses.text: Now the emperor had charged both Meletius and the rest who were able to speak to expound to the multitude the text "The Lord formed me in the beginning of his way, before his works of old" (Prov.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 27:16
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 27:18
verses.text: lxx), and he ordered skilled writers to take down on the spot what each man said, with the idea that in this manner their instruction would be more exact.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 27:19
verses.text: First of all Georgius of Laodicea gave vent to his foul heresy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 27:20
verses.text: After him Acacius of Caesarea propounded a doctrine of compromise far removed indeed from the blasphemy of the enemy, but not preserving the apostolic doctrine pure and undefiled.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 27:21
verses.text: Then up rose the great Meletius and exhibited the unbending line of the canon of the faith, for using the truth as a carpenter does his rule he avoided excess and defect.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 27:22
verses.text: Then the multitude broke into loud applause and besought him to give them a short summary of his teaching.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 27:23
verses.text: Accordingly after showing three fingers, he withdrew two, left one, and uttered the memorable sentence, "In thought they are three but we speak as to one".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 27:24
verses.text: Against this teaching the men who had the plague of Arius in their hearts whetted their tongues, and started an ingenious slander, declaring that the divine Meletius was a Sabellian.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 27:25
verses.text: Thus they persuaded the fickle sovereign who, like the well known Euripus, easily shifted his current now this way and now that, and induced him to relegate Meletius to his own home.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 27:26
verses.text: Euzoius, an open defender of Arian tenets, was promptly promoted to his place; the very man whom, then a deacon, the great Alexander had degraded at the same time as Arius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 27:27
verses.text: Now the part of the people who remained sound separated from the unsound and assembled in the apostolic church which is situated in the part of the city called the Palaea.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 27:28
verses.text: For thirty years indeed after the attack made upon the illustrious Eustathius they had gone on enduring the abomination of Arianism, in the expectation of some favourable change.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 27:29
verses.text: But when they saw impiety on the increase, and men faithful to the apostolic doctrines both openly attacked and menaced by secret conspiracy, the divine Meletius in exile, and Euzoius the champion of heresy established as bishop in his place, they remembered the words spoken to Lot, "Escape for thy life"; and further the law of the gospel which plainly ordains "if thy right eye offend thee pluck it out and cast it from thee".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 27:30
verses.text: The Lord laid down the same law about both hand and foot, and added, "It is profitable for thee that one of thy members should perish and not that thy whole body should be cast into hell".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 27:31
verses.text: Thus came about the division of the Church.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 28:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 28:2
verses.text: —About Eusebius, Bishop of Samosata.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 28:3
verses.text: The admirable Eusebius mentioned above, who was entrusted with the common resolution, when he beheld the violation of the covenant, returned to his own see.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 28:4
verses.text: Then certain men who were uneasy about the written document, persuaded Constantius to dispatch a messenger to recover it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 28:5
verses.text: Accordingly the emperor sent one of the officers who ride post with relays of horses, and bring communications with great speed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 28:6
verses.text: On his arrival he reported the imperial message, but, "I cannot," said the admirable Eusebius, "surrender the deed deposited with me till I am directed so to do by the whole assembly who gave it me".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 28:7
verses.text: This reply was reported to the emperor.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 28:8
verses.text: Boiling with rage he sent to Eusebius again and ordered him to give it up, with the further message that he had ordered his right hand to be cut off if he refused.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 28:9
verses.text: But he only wrote this to terrify the bishop, for the courier who conveyed the dispatch had orders not to carry out the threat.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 28:10
verses.text: But when the divine Eusebius opened the letter and saw the punishment which the emperor had threatened, he stretched out his right hand and his left, bidding the man cut off both.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 28:11
verses.text: "The decree," said he, "which is a clear proof of Arian wickedness, I will not give up".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 28:12
verses.text: When Constantius had been informed of this courageous resolution he was struck with astonishment, and did not cease to admire it; for even foes are constrained by the greatness of bold deeds to admire their adversaries success.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 28:13
verses.text: At this time Constantius learned that Julian, whom he had declared Caesar of Europe, was aiming at sovereignty, and mustering an army against his master.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 28:14
verses.text: Therefore he set out from Syria, and died in Cilicia.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book II 28:15
verses.text: Nor had he the helper whom his Father had left him; for he had not kept intact the inheritance of his Father's piety, and so bitterly bewailed his change of faith.
